title: senior royals air view on brexit
story: The depth of the nation’s deepening isions over Britain’s EU withdrawal have been identied by the  year-old monarch as a crisis issue.In a rare intervention on current affairs, she issued a plea for “respect” and “a coming together” on Thursday night.Buckingham Palace sources have revealed that the Queen has also now asked her family to engage publicly to promote compromise and a less embittered debate.Speeches and public comments from Prince Charles and his sons William and Harry are now being planned.The Queen’s intervention is being seen as a boost for embattled Theresa May, coming just a few days before a crucial Commons showdown on Tuesday to keep her Brexit deal alive.A Palace source said last night: “Her Majesty would never try to influence a vote.“Seeking to raise the tone of public debate, urging cooperation not conflict amongst those with power and influence - that is the job of her and her family. There will be more to come in the weeks and months ahead.”It also emerged yesterday that Buckingham Palace kept No completely in the dark over the Queen’s plea, so as not to embarrass Theresa May by any suggestion the desperate PM had asked for her help.Senior ministers heaped praise on the monarch’s words to Sandringham’s Women’s Institute on Thursday.In thinly veiled remarks about the impassioned Brexit debate, the Queen told them: “As we look for new answers in the modern age, I for one prefer the tried and tested recipes, like speaking well of each other and respecting dferent points of view coming together to seek out the common ground and never losing sight of the bigger picture.“To me, these approaches are timeless, and I commend them to everyone.”The intervention followed on from her Christmas address, in which she called for “treating the other person with respect” during “even with the most deeply held dferences”.Chancellor Philip Hammond said there is “huge wisdom” in the Queen’s words, adding: “It’s been our enormous strength over centuries that we have been able to find compromises that bring the nation together”.The PM’s official spokesman said: “The Prime Minister’s own view is that we should always show great respect for the point of view of others.”But after the vote there was speculation she was subtly backing the EU — by wearing a hat that matched the colours of the European Union flag.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: NewsUniversal Credit: Hundreds of thousands of people set to lose out on a weeks rentHousing associations say the problem will hit tenants who pay rent weekly in   - and demanded action from the DWP to close the "bizarre" loopholeShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsHousing associations say many will make  rent payments in   - not  "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailHundreds of thousands of Universal Credit claimants are set to lose out on a weeks rent next year thanks to a major glitch, housing associations have warned. Campaigners demanded action from the Department for Work and Pensionsto close the loophole after it was branded bizarre and unfair. The problem hits council and social housing tenants who pay rent once a week. Many will make  rent payments in   because the financial year has  Mondays. Yet they are due the same amount of Universal Credit asthey paid  weeks, because the six-in-one benefit is calculated dferently. DWP officials insisted today there are no plans to change the system because it would be too complicated. But Catherine Ryder, Head of Policy at the National Housing Federation, told the Mirror: It’s a really serious situation. This whole mess is entirely avoidable. Ministers have to act now to sort it out.  Labour MP Ruth George, who has raised the issue face-to-face with DWP chief Amber Rudd, added: Having  weeks of rent in a year is an anomaly of the system, it’s not anyone’s fault. So to refuse to compensate tenants on Universal Credit is a bizarre decision that will leave claimants even more out of pocket. The problem, raised by the NHF and first reported by Inside Housing, is expected to affect Universal Credit claimants who pay weekly rent once every six years. The NHF says that because UC is paid monthly, it is calculated using a formula that effectively takes  of a claimants weekly rent payments and ides the total by . But there are  weeks plus one day in each year. That means every six years or so, a tenant has to make  rent payments, not .   Housing associations say the issue will come to a head in   because rent day is usually Monday, and the year has  Mondays. Rochdale Boroughwide Housing expects , tenants to lose out by an average of pound each, while Bolton at Home expects , to lose out by pound each. The NHF, which represents housing associations, says the majority of claimants have their entire rent paid by UC, while others receive a contribution towards it. That means the majority of those affected are set to lose out on a weeks worth of rent, according to the NHF. Ms Ryder said: “To solve this, the Government only needs to make a small change – but it’s one that will help hundreds of thousands of people across the country. Otherwise, people will lose out and possibly end up falling behind with their rent.  Last month Work and Pensions Secretary Amber Rudd told MPs the issue was one of quite a few bugs in the system and said: We will address itand I will come back to you on it. But today DWP officials claimed change would be complicated and lead to confusion and said the average cost over six years was p a week. A spokesman said: A key principle of Universal Credit is that it simplies the benefit system and the Department has no plans to amend the regulations for assessing housing costs. “Some social housing providers have moved to charging new tenants on a monthly basis to overcome any challenges on the rare occasion a  week charging year may occur.” Shadow Work and Pensions Secretary Margaret Greenwood said it showed the system was too “rigid”. She added: “The Government needs to stop the roll out of Universal Credit as a matter of urgency and deliver a social security system that supports people rather than pushing them into poverty.”

title: yvette cooper plan doesnt block
story: NewsopinionYvette Cooper: My plan doesnt block Brexit - it just gives us more timeThe Home Affairs committee chair says time is running out and we need a bit of calm, common senseShareCommentsByYvette CooperMP:,  JAN NewsopinionYvette Cooper has put forward a plan to give Parliament some breathing room "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email The Prime Minister’s Brexit process is in a complete mess.Everyone is shouting at each other but time is running out and we need a bit of calm, common sense. Theresa May’s Deal was heavily defeated because people on all sides think it’s a bad deal which weakens us abroad and undermines our hand in future trade negotiations ahead. But the Prime Minister has left this so late that I’m worried we are going to end up drting into a chaotic No Deal by accident instead of getting a workable deal in place. That’s not fair on the families, manufacturing industry and communities who would be hit. WTO tarfs on food would mean higher prices for overstretched families.   Right wing Tories like Jacob Rees Mogg say that No Deal is the best outcome. But they aren’t the ones who will sufferprices go up. It’s also not fair on NHS patientsborder delays hold up crucial medicines. I’ve been contacted by local manufacturers and small businesses who would be hit by delays and customs costs.   The Government should be standing up for British manufacturing not making things harder. The police say No Deal would mean losing crucial European criminal information systems they use to stop criminals and terror suspects on our streets and at our border with no time to get equivalent alternatives in place. That’s why I am calling for common sense. If Theresa May hasn’t got a plan by the end of February, Parliament should be able to vote on whether to extend Article  for a few months to try to get a proper, workable deal in place. The cross-party bill I’ve put forward does not block Brexit, revoke article  or overturn the referendum result, nor should it.   It just allows Parliament to decidewe need more time to avoid No Deal. It’s unpopular to say everyone might need more time, especially when it’s because the Prime Minister has made such a mess of things. But sometimes we just have to be honest so families and communities don’t lose out.

title: how sports directs mike ashley
story: NewsHow Sports Directs Mike Ashley turned £, loan into £.billion empireEXCLUSIVE: The Mirror tracked down the Newcastle United owners first store - now selling security equipment - to find outAshley is the saviour or scourge of the high streetShareCommentsByGraham HiscottHead of Business:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsMike Ashley controls a rapidly growing retail empire "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Brash billionaire Mike Ashley controls a rapidly growing retail empire and has even claimed he can “save the high street”. The boss of Sports Direct , , snapped up stricken House of Fraser and Evans Cycles late last year, staged a boardroom coup at struggling Debenhams, owns stakes in a host of well-known names and is in the running to buy music chain HMV.But the tracksuit tycoon’s journey to the business big league began in a small shop opposite a pub more than  years ago. The Mirror tracked down his first store – now a shop selling security equipment – in Maidenhead, Berks, which he opened at the age of , with the help of a pound, loan from parents Keith and Barbara. Ross Wilson knew Mr Ashley at the time as they were both talented squash players and recalls how, even at , Ashley was driven to succeed.   “Mike was someone who wanted to rule the world,” accountant Mr Wilson, , told the Mirror. “I knew him very well through squash. He was very competitive. He liked winning and he was very clear where he was going in le. “Even at that age, he wanted to be in business and he wanted to succeed.” Sources say it was while Mr Ashley was working in a Maidenhead sports club that he hit upon turning a sideline into the start of a business. One of his early employees says: “He learnt that you could make good money from reshyshyshyshystringing rackets.” She describes Mr Ashley, whom she worked for when he later opened a bigger shop just up the same road in Maidenhead, as a “good boss”.  Yet he is now seemingly liked and loathed in equal measure. Many of Newcastle United s Toon Army, which he bought in  and apparently tried to sell on ious occasions, can’t wait to see the back of him.And he has clashed with unions over working conditions for his staff, with an investigation in  claiming locals near Sports Direct’s vast Shirebrook depot, in Derbyshire, knew it as “the gulag”. It’s a far cry from his beginnings. Michael James Wallace Ashley was born in Walsall, West Midlands, in , where his dad, Keith, was a manager at a food distribution depot. He has a brother, John, who has been heavily involved in the building of Mike’s empire. The family moved when the boys were young to Burnham, Bucks, a village on the edge of Slough. Mr Ashley went to co-educational Burnham Grammar School and old schoolmate Martin Blackmun says of him: “He wasn’t one of the popular kids and never had a girlfriend but he wasn’t a nerd either.”  Swedish glamour arrived at the school in the shape of future weathergirl and TV presenter Ulrika Jonsson and her sister, who moved there.“Everyone wanted to go out with them – I bet Mike did,” says Mr Blackmun. He may not have succeeded then but, years later, Mr Ashley met and later married Linda, a Swedish-born economics graduate. They wed in , were married for  years, went through a poundmillion orce and have since rekindled their relationship. The couple have three children – Oliver, , Anna, , and Matilda, . Mr Ashley gradually opened a large chains of shops and, in , changed the company’s name to Sports Soccer. One of his knacks was buying big-name moribund sporting brands such as Dunlop, Slazenger, Lonsdale and Karrimor and breathing new le into them. The company, renamed Sports Direct, floated on the stock market in , netting Mr Ashley poundmillion.   But his highly unorthodox style has seen him clash with the City. A High Court case in  heard claims he hosted management meetings in a pub when, on one occasion, he drank  pints and vomited into a fireplace. His wealth is now estimated at pound.billion and as well as the private helicopter, which he uses to commute to Shirebrook, he and Linda have also owned a string of luxurious homes in this country and around the world. He is also known to love gambling. On one trip to the casino he is said to have won pound.million on a single spin of the roulette wheel. However, there was also the time it was claimed he lost poundmillion in two hours in a Newcastle casino. What Mr Ashley plans to do with House of Fraser, plus potentially Debenhams and embattled HMV, is also a bit of a gamble, according to seasoned industry watchers. One former adviser told the Mirror: “He is an opportunist, a deal-maker but also a first-class retailer. But I can’t second guess him – I have given up trying to do that.” And he had this assessment of the tycoon: “He is a flawed genius. One of the flaws is that he is not everyone’s cup of tea. He’s also flawed in that he has lots of baggage.” Last November, Sports Direct issued a statement declaring that “Mike Ashley has vowed to save the high street”. Yet a month later, he said he is “not Father Christmas” and that the high street is “dying”. Whatever the case, and whatever his plans, Mike Ashley has certainly come a long way from that first small shop in Maidenhead.

title: eight strangest things people married

Following the recent news that a woman plans to marry her duvet, weddings no longer seem to have to involve two living humans anymore. Amanda Sparrow Large - Pirate ghost A woman who married the ghost of a pirate has revealed she has split from her -year-old husband and has issued a warning. Laura Mesi - Herself They sayyou cant love yourself - how can you love somebody   Italian fitness trainer Laura Mesi’s took this saying literally though after celebrating a fairytale wedding... to herself. Amanda Rodgers - Dog Dog owner Amanda Rodgers took her puppy love to extreme s when she decided to marry her pet pooch Sheba in August . Mrs Rogers, from South London, married a human husband  years ago but that union was short lived. So this time she decided to try a dferent approach when she went for walkies down the aisle in Split, Croatia, in front of  guests.   Sal - Computer game character The Japanese groom married his fantasy bride - literally. story: NewsInstagram mum who posts lestyle advice for busy parents filmed beating son, Olga Shvetsova, , from Ukraine, was caught on shopping centre CCTV kicking the young boy and later blamed her actions on "fatigue"ShareCommentsByWill Stewart:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news world-news video instagram-mum-attacks-own-son-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum who posts lestyle advice on Instagram for busy parents has been caught abusing her six-year-old son.Olga Shvetsova, , was filmed kicking and slapping the young boy at a shopping centre play area - but later blamed it on fatigue and emotional tiredness. The Ukrainian blogger only stopped when a female employee ran to intervene and separated her from son Vitalik. “She was shouting – ‘I hate you’ – and all that sort of stuff,” said an eyewitness. Another said: “She was totally insane.”  Natalia, manager of the play area, said: “When the child is being kicked in his back – it is not at all a calm way to behave. “All our staff were stunned.” Police in Zaporizhia, Ukraine, were called but took no action, yet a scandal erupted after the shocking CCTV footage was released on the web. Shvetsova was hit by a wave of revulsion in messages posted to her account, which she then deleted, and on other social media. One said: “This is the true face of Instagram mums.”   Other angry comments said: “There is nothing maternal in her behaviour, there is nothing human about it either.” Shvetsova - who has previously posted from London in her ‘how to have-it-all’ account - admitted kicking her son, and also spanking him in a videoed rant where she confessed that she took her stress and exhaustion out on her son. “I throw tantrums from time to time,” she said, as she drove her car. “Didn’t it happen to you    “If you are a kind of person who never shouted at her child, who never hit her child – I am very proud of you… “I am a dferent person. I can shout, I can spank, I can reprimand. This is me, just as I am….” She complained that it was “hard to raise two children on your own” - her other son is Mark, two - when her husband was often at work and “does not live at home for weeks on end”.  She said: I get tired very often…” But she made clear: “I am not executing myself for having done this.” She claimed: “It is a stupid topic for discussion. “It is better to discuss shoes or knickers than some conflict… “There was the reason for this situation, and it was not about Vitalik. “But I do not want to share my problems with others.”   The Instagram mum then claimed she was suffering from “fatigue and emotional tiredness”. Her son “did not get any bruises”, she said. “He is not hungry, he is at home and he is being fed well, we do not beat him for breakfast, lunch and dinner, so please… “He has lots of toys, he goes to sports every day, he has holidays, he lacks nothing. “Please do not worry about him, he is doing well. “He is not living with his grandparents, nannies are not bringing him up, I am doing everything myself, using my own forces, nobody is helping me.   “So when I explode sometimes, you should understand that it comes from fatigue and emotional tiredness. “It is hard to raise two children on your own. “My husband is working all the time, he often goes on business trips, sometimes he does not live at home for weeks on end. “I am recording all this not in order to justy myself. “I am recording it for those who punished their kids in the same way, who feel not quite right about something. “Girls, it does happen to all of us. “When you are doing everything on you own and nobody is helping you, no grandparents, no nannies, naturally anything can happen.   “Do not execute yourself for it. “For me it is a task to work on myself, on my time management, to see where I am exhausting myself and where I should get more rest.” But other mothers hit back on social media. “The worst thing is that there is nothing about love for her child in this video. “Fed well, dressed well, I am on my own, no nannies, so I am a hero… wait, honey, and see what happens in some  or  years ” Another critic said: “In a normal county she would have been jailed already and deprived of parental rights. “Thanks to Ukrainian legislation, such socially dangerous creatures feel free in our society.”

title: woman 34 who lives wild
story: NewsEx-teacher lives in the wild with her mountain man and washes hair with URINEMiriam Lancewood and her partner Peter have lived in the wild for years and hunt their own food as well as brush their teeth with ash and charcoalShareByElaine McCahillAssistant News Editor:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsMiriam Lancewood, , lives off the grid with her mountain man boyfriend who is  years older than her "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA former sports teacher who quit her job to live in the wild washes her hair with URINE to get rid of dandruff and hunts her own food. Miriam Lancewood, , lives off the grid with her mountain man partner Peter, . The couple have been living in the wilderness for almost nine years and the one thing that Miriam misses the most isnt central heating or a proper bed - but shampoo. She explained that during their first winter in the wild she suffered from a bad bout of dandruff and had to come up with a home made solution to get rid of it. In the first winter away, I was suffering from dandruff, Miriam told Mamamias No Filter podcast.   Peter said hed heard something about the Eskimos up north who treat their dandruff with morning urine. I thought Id give it a go. What does it matter  Miriam, who is originally from Wehl in the Netherlands, said she relieved herself into a little tin before wetting her hair with some water. Then I poured the tin of morning urine over my head. I waited until I could smell the urine, and then I washed it off with soap. It works very well, she said. Washing her hair with pee is just one of many unusual things Miriam does to maintain basic hygiene while living off the grid. She also uses charcoal and ash to brush her teeth and a mooncup when shes on her period.   Speaking to the Mirror previously, Miriam said sickness, along with food, is one of their key concerns. They cannot call for an ambulance or medical assistance as they have no phones. And medical attention is often at least several days or weeks away. She added: Peter once got sick with malaria. There were no doctors and we were in the middle of the jungle. Its a very scary moment when you dont have any emergency resources. We just have to be very careful. We have a very big First Aid kit and had medicines with us for malaria. We also have to be very careful not to get in an accident. If you break a leg it would be so bad. The pair packed up their bags in  bringing just a backpack with them. We got rid of all of our belongings [when we left in ], and I had left only what we needed, she recalled. We realised you really need very little. You need two shorts, three shirts, one woollen jumper, one long [trouser], one pair of leggings, and a couple of pairs of socks. Not much.  Miriam says their first three months living in the wild were very dficult. They always have a back-up of supply of some food - which includes a very precise calculation of tea bags - but with animals scarce and her technique unpractised, they were in danger of getting hungry. My very first hunt was possum and I had to hit it on the head and I couldnt do it properly, and it didnt die, said Miriam. The animal was looking at me with these afraid eyes. I was panicked, shaking with fear. I just wanted to give up. I thought I would go hunting so I practised with my bow and arrow on a target in the garden. I thought that would be good enough for when I went hunting. I envisioned myself as a film version of Robin Hood. But in practice it was so dficult because I couldnt see any animals. I was so disappointed with myself and my hunting. I wanted to give up and had no stamina to keep going. After a few months the situation improved and they moved to an area with more animals, with possum becoming a staple. She has also switched to occasionally using a rle - a quicker and more effective hunting tool. Miriam says she does miss her family and friends, who she sees around once every three years.  They also ask hunters to post letters for them when they meet them on their travels. However, Miriam said she wouldnt trade her le to go back to working in a city. Her reality now is a far cry from when she worked as a special needs teacher in New Zealand, a job in which she found herself constantly stressed. I certainly wouldnt go back to having a job and being in a city and having a so-called normal le. I would hate to have a monotone existence where we know what we are doing next week, living round the clock where the clock is ruling your le. I have been so surprised by how much energy you get from living in nature. I think this is actually our natural state. Our ancestors lived the way we do now. Its amazing how much energy you get from just living in the forest. Compared to the mountains around me, Im very small. Your fears and worries get even smaller.Woman in the Wilderness by Miriam Lancewood is published on  November by Piatkus, and is available from Amazon.

title: copenhagen urban designer says dundee waterfront road system like something from the 1950s
story: One of the masterminds behind Copenhagen’s urban regeneration has lambasted Dundee’s Waterfront project.Mikael Colville-Andersen was in Dundee last week as a keynote speaker at the Sustrans Raising the Standards event.The urban developer, who was one of the key figures in transforming Copenhagen and rejuvenating cycling culture in the Danish capital, was not impressed with Dundee’s Waterfront design.mdash Colville-AndersenJanuary , While Mikael liked the VA building itself, he took umbrage with the surrounding road system, describing it as “something from the s”.He said: “I got out of the train station and saw the VA and thought, ‘oh that’s great’.“But the dominance of cars is so old-fashioned. You can’t just build a pretty building and leave it at that. You can’t fence it in like that.“I think Dundee should start improving by stopping, before it’s gone too far. Cycling is the future. It’s not going away.“There always will be cars, of course, but the days of an automobile dictatorship are over in most cities. Dundee wouldn’t want to get left behind.”He did have some kind words for the city.“You have a lot of beautul old streets in Dundee and there has been some effort into making the roads nice,” he said.

title: dundee council wants to build 35 homes to become its first social housing scheme for several years
story: Dundee City Council has put forward its first plans to build social housing for several years.The proposal, to build a new social housing development in the north east of the city, has been submitted to planning officers by the council’s own architects.It outlines plans to build  homes on land at Murrayfield Place, Murrayfield Drive, Whitfield Avenue and Murrayfield Terrace.A number of the one and two-storey homes would be adapted for tenants with disabilities as well as for those with additional needs.The homes would be the first “in-house” developed homes from the local authority for “quite some time”, according to city architect Ray Low.Mr Low previously told the Tele the local authority has tended to partner up with housing associations such as Hillcrest in order to build new social homes.A flats complex which stood on the site, close to the former Longhaugh Quarry, was demolished in  to make way for the new development.Former residents had branded the old buildings an “eyesore”.A number of the flats had been vacant for some time at the point they were demolished, and the building had become a frequent target for vandals.The plans were warmly welcomed by locals when first suggested at a community meeting last August.Documents included with the application show the homes would be made with brick cladding, fitting in with other housing developments in the areaAs the local planning authority, Dundee City Council is unable to comment on its own applications.Councillors also cannot comment on upcoming applications until they go to committee.However, the design and access statement for the scheme concluded: “The proposed development makes best and most appropriate use of land previously developed for residential use on this brownfield site with the addition of  plots of much needed residential accommodation.“The proposed dwellings sit comfortably in their locality and respect the adjacent properties in terms of design and protection of amenity and they create high-quality living spaces for future occupiers.”The council has until March  to consider whether or not to approve the application.

title: dundee social enterprise hosts burns supper with scottish music and dancing
story: Local social enterprise Uppertunity is hosting a Burns supper with a twist this weekend.The charity, based at The Circle building on Staffa Place, will hold its Oor Burns Lunch at the community hub on Sunday from noon-pm.For a £ entry fee, the Oor Burns Lunch includes a three-course lunch which is suitable for all dietary requirements, as well as Scottish music and dancing.A piper will accompany the address to the haggis, and the meal will be followed by a choir performance by the group Better: Taygither.It is the third Burns lunch Uppertunity has held.The non-profit organisation provides personal development opportunities and inclusive social opportunities for dozens of local adults with additional support needs.To buy tickets for Oor Burns Lunch, call Danielle Gaffney du Plooy on   or email danielledp@uppertunity.

title: dundee united could launch ambitious move for ex aberdeen star peter pawlett
story: Dundee United could launch an ambitious move for wide man Peter Pawlett before the transfer window closes.The -year-old former Aberdeen star has been with MK Dons since the summer of  and, signicantly, it was United boss Robbie Neilson who signed him for the English outfit.His game time there this season has been limited but he has ed to the starting line-up in recent weeks and that could see the League Two side demand a fee for him.It was with the Dons up north the pacey winger made his name and, in  years at Pittodrie, he made over  appearances.His proven track record in the top flight and past association with the manager makes him an obvious target as the Terrors look to put together a squad that doesn’t just get back to the Premiership but does well there.If the former Scotland U  international does join up it would take the January arrivals at Tannadice to six.A busy month so far has seen Aidan Nesbitt, Cammy Smith, Morgaro Gomis, Ian Harkes and, on Wednesday, goalkeeper Ross Laidlaw all fixed up.And, including Pawlett, that number could rise by another two or even three by the time the window closes in a week.Meanwhile, gaffer Robbie has set his charges the challenge of finishing the month at the top of the Championship by getting all three points tonight at Ayr.United go into the clash at Somerset Park level on points with their second-place hosts, though Ayr have a game in hand over their rivals, and three off top-of-the-tree Ross County, who play on Saturday.Robbie said: “If we can end the January window up at the top of the league it would be great for us and still have a little bit of the transfer period to get a couple of players in as well.”

title: dundee uniteds new signing from bournemouth faces race against time to be ready for ayr united
story: Dundee United have continued their January transfer window signing spree by completing a loan deal for defender Charlie Seaman until the end of the season.The -year-old right-back arrives from English Premier League outfit Bournemouth.“Charlie is an exciting, attacking full-back,” said Tangerines boss Robbie Neilson.“I am pleased to get it over the line. We have had him watched and he is highly-rated at Bournemouth.“He will add quality to the right-hand side of our team.”It’s not clear yet whether the new man will make the squad for tonight’s Championship trip to face Ayr United at Somerset Park.The deal requires international clearance and it’s touch and go whether it will arrive in time.

story: Dundee have signed James Horsfield on loan from Scunthorpe United until the end of the season.The right-back, who has also played a number of games in midfield throughout his career, came through the youth ranks at Manchester City and after loan spells at Doncaster Rovers and NAC Breda made a permanent move to the Dutch side in .The -year-old joined Scunthorpe last summer and featured  times in the first half of the season for the Glanford Park side.Horsfield will wear number  this season.

story: Laurie Ellis will be leaving the Dundee United, the Tele understands.He arrived as assistant manager to Ray McKinnon in  and continued in that role under Csaba Laszlo.When Robbie Neilson arrived in October there was speculation the ex-Raith Rovers stalwart, whose contract is up in the summer, would be replaced by Dunfermline’s Stevie Crawford.While that didn’t happen, Gordon Forrest did become the new No  earlier this month and yesterday saw confirmation of ex-Rangers man Lee McCulloch as striker coach until the end of the season, at least.

title: local businesses object to proposed 11m retail park
story: Arbroath business owners concerned about the future of the High Street have joined together to gauge public option about a proposed retail park planned for the gateway to the town.Members of Arbroath Retail and Business Association are opposed to the multi-million-pound development by Brackenbrae Investments Ltd, which promises to bring several big-name retailers, including food outlets, to a site at Elliot.Chairman Kaleem Ahmed, , has lodged an objection with Angus Council against the proposed £ million plan.The group is urging shoppers to submit their views on the scheme in the hope it can persuade the local authority to protect the town’s existing traders.Steven Thomson, director of Innes Associates acting on behalf of the developer, said the proposed retail park would create jobs and provide a “signicant boost” to the local economy.

title: more than half of dundee public transport users struggle to afford peak fares
story: More than half of Dundonians who use public transport are struggling to afford peak fares.A poll revealed people who use public transport from Dundee are delayed on average twice each week, with % of respondents calling peak time the most uncomfortable time to travel.The research, compiled by Censuswide Scotland, showed more than three-quarters of Dundonians using public transport think it is unfair to charge more for a peak fare than it is for an off-peak fare.Commuters at Dundee railway station agreed with the findings. Josh Miller, , a barista who travels to Dundee from Carnoustie, said: “I think the buses are OKyou get a weekly or monthly ticket but they are not advertised well enough.#Rail fares are extortionate. Evenyou are going one way, sometimes it works out better to get aticket than a single.”Leanne Millar, , a student from Stobswell, said the price makes it unaffordable to travel longer distances.She said: “Prices are steep, even just for a single fare. I usually travel by train from Dundee to Perth every weekend so it adds up.“I have never really bought a railcard because there isn’t really a good enough student discount and they won’t allow you to show your student ID for a discount.”A Scottish Government spokesman said: “Overall, Scottish fares are % lower than the UK average and we already meet around two-thirds of the cost of rail passenger services in Scotland.”A spokeswoman for Xplore Dundee said: “We have a wide range of ticket prices to suit all pockets and the cheapest way of buying your bus journeys is by monthly direct debit, which gives you unlimited travel on all our services for just £. a day.“It’s the second year in a row that we have frozen the prices of our multi-journey tickets, and our mobile tickets offer a discount, too, over the paper versions.”Douglas Robertson, commercial director of Stagecoach East Scotland, said: “Travel on Stagecoach services across Dundee costs just £. per day for a regular traveller using our Dundee megarider ticket.#Our range offers unlimited travel across the region and offers great value to those travelling regularly.”

title: now open dundee path smoother and better lit after 376k investment
story: A six-figure investment into Dundee’s walking and cycling infrastructure is now open to the public.More than £, was put into new surfacing, a boundary fence and improved lighting on part of a shared use path through the Port of Dundee.Lynne Short, convener of Dundee City Council’s city development committee, said: “This is a flat route alongside the river and now that it is smoother and better lit it will be easier for cyclists and pedestrians to use.“The investment in these enhancements was specically made to encourage walking and cycling, not just for leisure and pleasure, but also as a useful and practical alternative to using the car.”David Webster, senior port manager at the Port of Dundee added: “The cycle path through the port has always been popular and with the improvements to the route and the surface, even more people can enjoy a safe journey on bike or foot to and from the city centre.”The access to the path is part of an agreement between the city council and Forth Ports.It forms part of the national and North Sea cycle routes as well as the local Green Circular.

title: scott allardice leaves dundee united after nine years
story: Scott Allardice has left Dundee United after nine years.The Dundonian came up through the club#s youth ranks but has struggled to break into the first team, making six league appearances.Allardice, , spent time on loan at East Fe last season and Dunfermline this term.A club statement said the midfielder-cum-defender has left the club #after both parties mutually agreed to end his contract.#Allardice said: “I#d like to thank everyone at Dundee United for the past nine years with a special thanks to all the academy coaches I worked with.#Ideally, the last  months would have gone better, but it is the right time to move on to a new, fresh challenge where.#I wish the club all the best for the rest of the season.”

title: second charity football match in aid of young dundee dad lee who took his own life
story: A second charity football match in aid of a young Dundee dad who took his own le after suffering from depression is to be held in the summer.Lee Welsh, , was found dead at his Peddie Street home in the city’s West End in August .At the time, his dad Phil said that Lee, whose daughter Poppy was then aged seven, had battled mental health issues for the previous nine years.Last year Lee’s childhood friend, Steve Martin organised a football match in memory of his mate which raised more than £, for the Dundee Association for Mental Health .The event was so successful that a second one has been organised for July  this year.It will be held at North End Park and this time the money raised will be donated to Art Angel on behalf of the Not in Vain for Lee charity.As well as football there will be other attractions on the day including a bouncy castle, face and henna painting, a pipe band, live music and a demonstration by Dundee Mods Scooter Club.Phil – who has actively raised awareness about mental health issues among young people since his son’s death – was thrilled with the turnout and the money raised last year.He said: “It really was an absolutely brilliant day.“We hope we can get the same response this year.“It’s all about looking to the future now in raising money for our mental health charities.”

title: Bid to create new whisky centre by Loch Ness
story: TALES of illicit whisky distilling on the shores of Loch Ness may feature soon in a new visitor centreplans for the facility get the go ahead from Highland Council.Hospitality and tourist operator Cobbs is teaming up with the Dingwall-based GlenWyvis Distillery to create what is being billed as the Loch Ness Whisky Experience.If approved by planners it will be sited in a redeveloped cottage by the lochside Clansman Hotel, which Cobbs owns.GlenWyvis Distillery opened in late  as the worldrsquos first  per cent community-owned, fully sustainable distillery producing single malt whisky and craft gin.It was denied permission to open its own on-site visitor centre last year amid concerns about accessibility, though it says it is still working with the council to resolve that situation.Highland Councils transport planning team are seeking more information on a number of matters related to the proposed Loch Ness development, including traffic impact and access to the A public road, but Cobbs managing director, Fraser Campbell, believes it is an exciting project with huge potential."Abriachan and the area around the Clansman Hotel was well known for illicit stills and I know the distillery has a lot of information and history which will feature at the visitor centre," he said."It is important we bring more tourists to the area and give them things to do when they are at Loch Ness."The Clansman runs fantastic boat trips, but not everyone wants to go on a boat so we want to bring other visitor experiences to the loch."We approached the distillery. They think itrsquos a great idea and we think its a great idea and of course it will be a great means of promoting their product."He added: "We get lots of bus tours from Invergordon to the hotel and this development will also help reduce traffic and help the environment because it means they will not have to spend half a day on the road travelling to a whisky experience where."GlenWyvis managing director John Mckenzie said: "This opportunity has come at the perfect time for GlenWyvis. It will give us access to a global audience and it will provide a great forum to engage with visitors who are interested in the story of whisky from a Highland community perspective. This is about the story of grass-roots distilling, distilling for the people, and, of course, that is what underpins the community ethos of GlenWyvis."The aim is to have the new visitor attraction up and running by this summer but to develop it further after that, providing both interactive and interpretative displays, as well as a retail facility.Saturday  Jan  : AM

title: Bucket loads of fun in store for Inverness
story: A CHILDRENrsquoS hospital charity is teaming up with one of Scotlandrsquos most iconic characters ndash and is on the hunt for someone to co-ordinate the Inverness end of the operation.This summer will see the Oor Wullie Big Bucket Trail rolled out across the country with more than  inidually decorated statues of the cheeky comic character set to grace city streets between June  and September .As well as drawing attention to the work of The Archie Foundation an auctioning off of the figures at the end of the event is also expected to raise thousands of pounds for its work in making hospital stays more pleasant for children.Around  of the statues are set to grace Inverness streets and an invitation has already been issued for creative types young or old to submit their ideas for how they should be designed.There is also a vacancy for a part-time artist co-ordinator to ensure the work is delivered by the June deadline.A spokesman for the foundation said the role would suit someone with an arts background who can co-ordinate submissions and manage artists.ldquoWe have just taken delivery of the fibre glass sculptures at a warehouse in Dundee and they will be distributed around the country in due course, he said.In terms of the designs to be applied to the statues he added: ldquoWhen we say we are looking for lsquoartistsrsquo to decorate these sculptures we are very flexible, because in Dundee we have already had one decorated by a group of children putting their handprints all over the sculpture. Sothere are community groups out there who would like to give their take on Oor Wullie we would be delighted to hear from them too.Design ideas can be submitted online until January  at www.oorwullie and applications for the co-ordinator post should be emailed to hello@archie.orgSaturday  Jan  : AM

title: Call for Inverness to get a share of cash for shop conversions
story: CONCERNS have been raised that Inverness could be denied a share of funding to help the hardest-pressed local high streets turn empty shops into housing.Mike Smith, manager of the cityrsquos Business Improvement Districtfears a move by the Federation of Small Businessesto persuade the Scottish Government to split a pound million fund between the poorest-performing high streets only could see a relatively buoyant Inverness miss out.ldquoI donrsquot think thatrsquos fair, he said.ldquoAll high streets are under certain pressures. Retail is a commercial venture and we do not think that public funds should be given tosupport one retail sector against another.ldquoI think this pound million should be fairly split on a population basis and should be used in an equal way to improve the infrastructure.Mr Smith stressed that some local authorities will already be investing in this way and their successes ldquoshould not be held against them.He said the redevelopment of Academy Streetrsquos former Farmfoods supermarket was ldquoa good example of shops being turned into homes in the city with the local authorityrsquos support.The development there will include  one-bedroom and  two-bedroom flats as well as four retail and office units on the ground floor.A spokesman for FSB nationally said: ldquoIt is far too early to tell which high streets will benefit from this fund.ldquoWersquore making the case for each local authority to use this money in the places that it could make the most dference.FSB Highlands and Islands development manager David Richardson said: ldquoRather than spreading the money too thinly for it to have any impact, the FSB wants it to be focused on ersying our hardest-pressed high streets and is calling for local authorities to establish new co-investment funds to improve and convert existing properties. We must make more of what wersquove already got. Allied to this is the need for joined-up thinking amongst public bodies. Given that thriving high streets and village centres are inextricably linked to the health and wellbeing of their communities, it is important that all interested parties work in partnership.Inverness Central councillor Bet McAllister said she would be calling on colleagues to get round the table for some strategic planning to make sure the city gets a share of the funding.She believes the rate of shop closures in the Highland capital and the long waiting list for homes puts the city at the front of the queue.She said: ldquoIrsquom going to have a chat with the city centre manager, David Hass, and get people around the table to see how we can get our hands on that money.Saturday  Jan  : AM

title: Chance to win a kilt and help Inverness charity
story: KILT wearers are being offered the chance to win themselves a custom-made kilt package worth pound to help an Inverness appeal.A made-to-measure kilt, tweed jacket and waistcoat are being raffled to raise money for the Haven Appeal to develop Scotlandrsquos first integrated centre for children and young people with multiple and complex needs.The raffle is being organised by Angus Beaton and Gary Smyth who teamed up to put the prize together.Both have family members with autism and also served together in the Queenrsquos Own Highlanders.Mr Beaton is a counter sales assistant at MacGregor Industrial Supplies in Henderson Road while Mr Smyth runs the family business, Scotkilt, in Harbour Road.ldquoI became aware of the Haven Appeal because my -year-old grandson, Kyle, was diagnosed with autism when he was very young, Mr Beaton said. ldquoHe would benefit from something like the Haven Centre.The pound million facility will have specialist indoor and outdoor play areas, respite flats, a community-run coffee shop and garden and offices.Mr Beaton and his colleagues at MacGregor Industrial Supplies raised pound for the appeal last year through raffles, bake sales and a tuck shop.Mr Smyth became involved in the appeal as he has a son with autism.ldquoAs like any family with this going on, it has its challenges and there needs to be more help in the Highlands for us all, he said.The jacket and waistcoat along with the kilt will be made for the winner at Scotkilt.The appeal, launched by the Elsie Normington Foundation and supported by the Inverness Courier, has raised pound. million towards the proposed Haven Centre to be built in Murray Road, Smithton.Tickets for the raffle, which will be drawn on March , cost pound each or people can donate via www.justgiving fundraising angus-beaton.Details of the project can be found on www.havenappeal.org.uk.Saturday  Jan  : AM

title: Demands to tear down Inverness eyesore that has lain empty for 20 years
story: FRUSTRATION is growing among community leaders over a lack of progress to tackle a long-standing eyesore within sight of Inverness Castle.B-listed Viewhill House has stood empty for more than  years and was in poor repair when it was ravaged by fire in .Since then, the roofless shell has remained a carbuncle on the city skyline, shrouded in scaffolding, overgrown bushes and weeds.Pat Hayden, chairwoman of Crown and City Centre Community Council, believes it is time to consider knocking it downthere are no feasible restoration plans for the building ndash once the home of Victorian engineer Joseph Mitchell and later a youth hostel.And a leading city chartered surveyor agreed, saying it was beyond economic repair.Mrs Hayden said the eyesore would ruin the view from the castle once it is turned into a visitor attraction, adding: ldquoThey are going to stand on the hill and look around them, see Viewhill and wonder what on earth it is.ldquoPersonally, I think it should be demolished. You cannot preserve something which is no longer viable. We have waited far too long for something to happen.She is due to meet Highland Council officials later this month to discuss the future of the site.Chartered surveyor Richard Smith, managing director of Allied Souter and Jaffrey, said Viewhill should come down.ldquoIt is worth absolutely nothing unless you get permission to demolish it because the renovation far outweighs its value, said Mr Smith, whose company handled the sale on behalf of the Youth Hostel Association.He also queried its listing which he claimed followed a hurried request from a council official and without a visit from the listings authority.ldquoIt was a bad listing from the point of view that it was not checked out properly, said Mr Smith, who gave a ldquostab-in-the-dark valuation of pound, for the site, based on permission for demolition and redevelopment for a residential property.At one time Viewhill was owned by building firm Ewen Gillies and later acquired by Magnus Propertieswhich is believed to be the present owner. The companyrsquos director has a correspondence address in County Antrim.Highland Council is not in active discussions with the owner and David Haas, Inverness city centre manager, said it was up to the owner to push forward any plans.ldquoAs a council, we recognise the importance of that site and will work with stakeholders who have responsibility for it to develop any opportunities, but at the moment we are not in a position to do that, he said.ldquoObviously, we are very keen to see it brought back into use.Inverness Central councillor Bet McAllister agreed action was now needed.ldquoI have spoken to other people who are really fed-up about it, she said. ldquoPeople think it is a disgrace.Highland Historic Buildings Trust previously pressed the case for the restoration and conversion of the property into eight-serviced apartments, but has been unable to raise the costs, estimated at pound. million in .Chairman John Duncan stressed the trust was not the owner or potential developer but got involved to try and find a solution.He said any application for demolition would have to be determined by the council and Historic Environment Scotland.In connection with another controversial Inverness building, aquestionmark hangs over when the former Eastgate Hostel will be demolished, despite previous assurances that eyesore would start to come down next week.Talks took placeon Thursdaybetween Highland Council and representatives acting for the owners of the building which has remained a fire-ravaged eyesore for  days now.Afterwards, neither party would confirm whether work would begin next week, although they insisted the meeting was ldquovery positive.Chiropodist Jim Crawford, whose business is nearby, called for the council to take out a compulsory purchase orderwork does not start by next Friday.ldquoThere has been no sign of activity so far, he said.ldquoIt is an absolute nonsense.Building consultant Gary Johnston, agent for the owners Imtaiz Ali and Mr Cheng, would not confirm when work would begin. All he could say was: ldquoEverything is going according to plan.David Haas, Highland Councilrsquos Inverness city manager, said matters were progressing in a constructive way.ldquoIt is very frustrating it has taken so many years to get to this stage but the principal owner has taken major steps in the last six months, he insisted.Saturday  Jan  : AM

title: Drive on to extend free parking in Inverness city centre
story: CITY businesses are pushing for an extension to free parking in the centre of Inverness as a year-long trial they have hailed as a success comes to an end.Backed by the Inverness Courier, Inverness Business Improvement Districtpersuaded Highland Council to introduce a system of free  minutes of on-street parking last year across a broad swathe of the city centre.Parking meters were converted to provide free tickets for  on-street spaces, after research suggested similar schemes have had a positive impact on footfall in other urban centres such as Perth.The trial period is now coming to an end and business figures, who argue it has been a hit, are hoping it will be extended ndash both in terms of the amount of time shoppers will be able to enjoy free parking for and the number of sites they can us.Local butcher Duncan Fraser who has premises in Queensgate said: ldquoThe businesses I have spoken to would like to see it extended to half an hour.ldquoFteen minutes is fine, but a bit tightyou have to go to a couple of shops or get caught up in the post office.ldquoWe certainly would not like to see this withdrawn.And David Miele, who runs the hugely successful Mielersquos Gelateria in Church Street, is also hoping councillors will look at making better use of the parking space available.ldquoThere are too many loading bays which lie empty for most of the day, he said.ldquoWhen wardens pass our premises customers basically get up and go out because they fear getting a ticket.ldquoI welcome the free parking and would like to see it increased.They are being backed in their calls by Inverness Central councillor and depute provost Bet McAllisterldquoIt has clearly been welcomed by the traders and enables people to get in to the town centre and attend to business, but you canrsquot do a lot in  minutes, she said.ldquoI would rather see it extended to half an hour so people can pop into a couple of shops, go to the library or even stop for a coffee.And she added: ldquoMany older people would benefit greatly from a longer stay.ldquoWe have to look at the bigger picture. The Victorian Market is generally used by older people and it needs more customers. Longer-stay free parking would help.BID manager Mike Smith said it believes the free parking has been beneficial.ldquoInverness BID subscribes to the view that parking is all part of the city centre marketing offer to the public, he said.ldquoWe appreciate the financial pressures Highland Council is under, but we should not lose sight of that mantra.Shane Manning, principal officer for traffic and planning at Highland Council, confirmed councillors are set to evaluate the schemersquos impact when the Inverness city area committee meets on February . They will decide at that point whether to continue with it.Saturday  Jan  : AM

title: Funding could lead to new life for Inverness park
story: A BOLD vision to transform a historic Inverness park into a vibrant green space and breathe new le into its dilapidated buildings could take a step forward later this month.Campaigners are exploring the possibility of transferring ownership of the Northern Meeting Park in Ardross Street to a community-run group in a bid to enable greater access to the venue.The Northern Meeting Park Group is now waiting to hear whether a funding application has been successful for a feasibility study to prepare a five-year business plan plus architectural reports and surveys.If all goes according to plan, the study could begin before the end of January while the long-awaited project could be achieved by the end of next year.The group is also looking for two trustees from the local community ndash taking in the neighbourhoods of Park, Balleary and Dalneigh and Columba ndash to join its -strong board.Chairman Jon Ford expects this year to be a busy one in trying to push forward the proposals for the -year-old park whose gates are usually kept locked.The group has applied for a grant from the Scottish Land Fund with advice from Highlands and Islands Enterprise and hopes to get match funding from the Architectural Heritage Fund.In total, the initial studies are expected to cost pound,.ldquoWe know there are a lot of other people out there also looking for funding but we are very optimistic, he said.ldquoThat would be the first stage. The next stage would be to apply for funding to acquire the Northern Meeting Park and have it transferred into community ownership.Highland Council would also have to agree to transfer ownership of the park.Mr Ford acknowledged there had been some resistance from a few councillors including those who had mistakenly thought the idea was to turn the park into a private business venture.ldquoNone of us likes change, he said. ldquoI can understand it on one level but not on another when you are talking about a publicly-owned asset which is kept locked up and not used especially as it is four acres of grass in the city centre which could be used for recreation.ldquoI cannot understand why people are resistant to that notion. In our view this is a way for Highland Council to think outside the box.Hundreds of people accessed the park during a two-week trial last summer when the gates were opened each day between am and pm.Mr Ford hopes a similar trial will be carried out around Easter.Anyone interested in becoming a trustee can contact the group via www.northernmeetingpark, or call  .Saturday  Jan  : AM

title: Go ahead for River Ness hydro scheme
story: A SPECTACULAR hydro electric scheme close to the heart of Inverness has been given the green light by Highland Council, and it is hoped it will not only be a source of power, but also an attractive feature on the River Ness.Council officials granted the application for the lsquoArchimedes screwrsquo to be built into the bank next to Holm Mills Bridge near the West Link distributor road but have placed a total of  conditions on the project to safeguard visual amenity, road and pedestrian safety.The project has been warmly welcomed with local councillor Alex Graham, he said: ldquoThis project was first mooted about three years ago and then it came back towards the end of last year. Historically hydro power was generated there in the s in the building that is now the ice-cream shop.ldquoIn the present climate I think it is a very welcome project, one that can not only generate power locally but also become a feature to be enjoyed by visitors and locals.Helen Smith, who is on Balleary Community Council, said: ldquoWe didnrsquot comment on it but it is tucked away quite far from residential buildings. But from my point of view, personally its fine, I remember there was hydro power there in the past and it might be quite attractive. Irsquod be surpriseit bothers any local residents.Saturday  Jan  : AM

title: Highland arts venue has strategy to combat fund gap
story: THE regionrsquos biggest arts venue has outlined how it must become more financially resilient.In its latest accounts, Eden Court in Inverness reported increased income and more expenditure in the year ending March ,  compared to the previous  months.Last year Eden Court lost pound, a year of funding ndashpound, from Creative Scotland and pound, from the Highland Council.A trusteesrsquo report the figures stated: ldquoThe principal risks identied are financial ones, particularly the effect of this yearrsquos signicant reduction in public funding.ldquoThe organisation must become more financially resilient by growing sources of earned income and building a safe level of reserves.ldquoAs public funding declines, the targets for earnings from trading activities necessarily increase, and the risk that these targets cannot be met also increases. At the same time, our cost base is likely to increase owing to inflationary pressures on resources.ldquoThis year we are working on a strategy for trading through our funding gap, increasing income from charitable trading, reducing costs wherever possible and developing partnerships to share services.ldquoAttention has also been focused on non-financial risks arising from the loss of some channels of regular communication with our major funders our relationship with both Creative Scotland and the Highland Council has been strengthened during the year to March ,  and subsequently.ldquoThe development of positive relationships with funders ndash public organisations and inidual philanthropists ndash remains a high priority and is a central part of Eden Courtrsquos financial strategy for the coming three years.Total income increased from pound,, in  to pound,, last year. For the same period, total expenditure moved from pound,, to pound,,.Total funds also went up from pound,, to pound,,.Advance ticket sales mean that Eden Courtrsquos cash flow position remains strong.The biggest event of the year was the Snow White panto, which sold more than , tickets for its  performances.The report stated: ldquoAttendance for the year has been unprecedented with audiences of , for live performances and , at film screenings. The financial contribution from live performances was pound, higher than budget, boosted by some musical performances in the summer months and an excellent result from our Christmas pantomime.The wholly owned subsidiary Eden Court Trading experienced a rise in turnover from pound,, in  to pound,, last year, and an increase in pre-tax profit from pound, to pound,.The report added: ldquoOver the past four years we have seen substantial growth in trading through our restaurant, cafeacute and bars, and also in sales of confectionary, show merchandise and programmes by our front of house team.ldquoOur trading activities in   resulted in a surplus of pound,, an increase of  per cent over the previous yearrsquos result.ldquoWe will also implement a new strategy to attract philanthropy from trusts and foundations, and from within our community.Saturday  Jan  : AM

title: Hope that Inverness special needs project can be saved
story: Highland Councilrsquos refusal to fund the Special Needs Action Projectin Inverness has triggered outrage across party lines with councillors and members of parliament queuing up to slam the local authority.Conservative councillor Andrew Jarvie, said: ldquoNot only is this a devastating blow for dozens upon dozens of vulnerable children and young people, it symbolises everything that is wrong with this council administration.Mr Jarvie complained the decision to refuse funding was taken in private, saying: ldquoThis secrecy and behind closed door decisions wreaked havoc on rural communities last year but I find it absolutely disgusting to inflict the same on the most vulnerable people in Highland.ldquoFor SNAP to run such a comprehensive and valuable year round service for pound, a year tells me that they are already managing their funds stringently and that any cut is a gross insult to both the organisation and its users.MP Drew Hendry met with SNAP management last week and he said: ldquoAnybody who knows about the great work SNAP do would also be very concerned by the uncertainty around their future and just how dficult it would be to replace the work that they do.ldquoA better way forward must be to secure their immediate future and to work with them to find sustainable funding for coming years.ldquoThis approach has worked successfully before and I have pledged to do what I can to support SNAP and the council to find a better outcome.Saturday  Jan  : AM

title: Inverness charity issues go orange plea for fundraising effort
story: INVERNESS charity Leorsquos Pride is encouraging people to lsquoGo orange for a dayrsquo as ambassadors in this yearrsquos Muscular Dystrophy UKevent on February .The national campaign has been running for three years and has so far made more than pound, by encouraging schools, workplaces and iniduals to wear orange for a day and make a donation to MDUK.Additionally those taking part can choose to wear sunglasses or even set up a mock-tail bar, in order to raise funds.Leorsquos Pride is a local organisation which was set up for Leo Flett, who is three-years-old and suffers from Muscular Dystrophy . Leorsquos mum Louise said: ldquoThe support we have had since starting almost a year ago is absolutely incredible and we continue to be touched by peoplersquos kindness and generosity.Mrs Flett said: ldquoWe are totally blown away by this yearrsquos response. We have been very lucky and honoured to have been asked to be ambassadors for the day this year by MDUK which means a lot to us considering wersquore still so new.The charity is raising money to continue their work finding new treatments and campaigning for better care and support for people with muscle-wasting conditions to ensure them the best possible quality of le.Muscular Dystrophy UK regional development manager, Dean Widd said: ldquoA huge thank you to everyone in Inverness looking to take part in the national Go Orange for a Day on February . We are delighted that over a dozen schools, clubs, academies and businesses have registered to take part in support of our Scottish family fund Leorsquos Pride.Mr Widd said: ldquoIt is thanks to the incredible efforts like this that we are able to continue to fund pioneering research into potential treatments for muscular dystrophy as well as supporting families. With more than , people in the UK living with muscular dystrophy and other muscle-wasting conditions, it is important to do whatever we can to make a dference.Leorsquos Pride is also organising an event in April called Pride  after last yearrsquos event which made over pound,.Saturday  Jan  : AM

title: Parents criticise new school bus service across Inverness
story: SCHOOL bus services have been in chaos since a council contract changed hands at the start of the month it has been claimed.Parents say a move to double up dedicated school runs with services for the general public since transport giant Stagecoach took over the Highland Council schools contract from DE Coaches on January  has seen pupils regularly forced to endure late-running and dangerously overcrowded buses.Police have also confirmed they are investigating allegations that pupils were threatened with a weapon on board a bus between Kirkhill and Charleston Academy on January .Mum Carol Paterson, whose daughter travels from Croy to Culloden Academy, said the problems are known about across Inverness.ldquoThe children at Croy are waiting sometimes up to  minutes in freezing conditions because the buses are now regularly late, she said.ldquoAnd when they board the bus there are not enough seats.Jools Lawson, whose daughter attends Charleston Academy, said: ldquoKids are regularly having to stand on a jam-packed bus or being put off altogether and told to wait for another one.ldquoThe service is disgusting and Stagecoach brush our complaints under the carpet.Posts from a private Facebook group set up for parents of pupils using school buses and shown to the Inverness Courier make clear the extent of unhappiness since the changeover.Other alleged incidents include children being put off a bus beside a busy main road without a pavement and two incidents involving Inverness Royal Academy pupils ndash one where a bus did not turn up at home time and another where the bus was too small to accommodate them.Highland Council has issued two separate statements in response to concerns raised ndash one with regard to a public service operating en route to Inverness Gaelic Primary stating it is unlikely to involve ldquoroutes which the public are likely to want to use and another on the Charleston Academy-Kirkhill route stating ldquomeasures have been put in place to make improvements.Despite this an online petition has been launched calling for the reinstatement of dedicated school services.Signed by almost  people so far it states: ldquoWhen putting our children on a school bus it used to be the case that it was only school children on these buses, therefore anyone travelling was accounted for and any incidents easily dealt with and tracked.ldquoNow we have opened the floodgates to allowing our children to be exposed to anything on these buses.Councillor for Culloden and Ardersier, Glynis Campbell-Sinclair, said Highland Council needs to launch its own investigation into whether there is a serious problem with how buses taking pupils to and from schools operate.ldquoThey cannot jam pack children onto buses like pilchards and hope there is not going to be an accident - especially in this weather, she said.ldquoEvery parent that sends their child to school by bus is depending on the council to ensure that happens safely.ldquoIt is the councilrsquos responsibility as corporate parent to ensure these children get to school safely.A spokeswoman for Stagecoach North Scotland said: ldquoSince we started operating the additional school contracts on January  there have been some issues with capacity we have identied and are working to resolve.ldquoWe are working closely with Highland Council to resolve these problems by issuing school children with passes allocating them to specic buses to prevent the overloading problems we have seen.She added that in terms of the issues raised by Mrs Paterson an additional bus is now running to and from Croy.Saturday  Jan  : AM

title: charlie house urges public to take on aberdeen 10k to raise cash for charity
story: Members of the public are being urged to sign up to take on a popular Aberdeen running challenge.Charlie House, which supports children and babies with complex disabilities and or le-limiting conditions, is offering spaces in the BHGE K Running Festival for keen runners, who will help to raise money for the charity’s Big Build Appeal.The event has been going for a number of years, with the main K event taking place alongside a fun run.It is the second time the charity has taken part.A total of  spaces are available for people to sign up to, which will see them support Charlie House.Those representing the charity are asked to raise a minimum of £.In November, Charlie House launched its Big Build Appeal, an £ million fundraising campaign to build a specialist support centre, which would be the first of its kind in the north-east, based in four acres of ground at Woodend Hospital.Rhona Miller, team fundraising manager at Charlie House, said: “This is our second year being involved with the BHGE K Running Festival.“We were delighted with the response gained from last year and hope this increases with further support from our fundraisers in May.”Money raised will go towards the campaign, which aims to build an eight-bedroom facility with associated family accommodation.As well as providing respite care for children and their families, it will also have a range of dferent facilities such as a sensory room, library, spa pool, craft room, teen den, soft play area, therapy room, star room for end-of-le care and bereavement, outdoor play area and sensory gardens, as well as adaptable meeting and office space for employees and medical staff.The BHGE K is to take place on May , and is organised by Sport Aberdeen, in partnership with BHGE and Aberdeen City Council. The route is based around Aberdeen’s beach and harbour area.It then moves along the Beach Esplanade, up King Street, through Seaton, along Golf Road and Urquhart Road before rejoining the route at the finish line. The K will start at .am, and the K at am.The K will begin at the Beach Leisure Centre and will loop past Pittodrie, and is open for children in P up to S.Wheelchair users are also encouraged to take part, with an adjusted start time of .am for the K, and .am for the K.Anyone interested in signing up to fundraise for Charlie House should contact fundraise@charliehouse.org.ukCharlie House was set up in , and as well as raising funds for the Big Build Appeal it also runs activity clubs, siblings clubs, annual adventure trips and it has its own community nurse, all which it fundraises for throughout the year.Charlie House launches £ million appeal to build specialist care centre for north-east children" src"https:www.eveningexpress fp news local charlie-house-launches--million-appeal-to-build-specialist-care-centre-for-north-east-children embed # secretDqXQqVJZls" data-secret"DqXQqVJZls" width"" "" title"#Charlie House launches £ million appeal to build specialist care centre for north-east children# # Evening Express" frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"

title: marian travels back to the hollow mountain
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsMy book about the project, Cruachan: The Hollow Mountain, was published to coincide with the th anniversary of its opening. Invited to join Cameron up at the Cruachan dam for the second of his two recent programmes, I was delighted to tramp the mighty mountain with Scotland’s Number one authority on outdoor pursuits.As an author and broadcaster, Cameron always has an eye on a good story, and so as well as asking me about the lack of health and safety regulations at the time the hydro project was being built, he also wanted to knowthere really was a murder during the construction. There was, as I told him, a body – but the body wasn’t identied, no arrests were made, no court case took place.It would be a shamethat construction period went down in history as an invasion of , workmen – #Tunnel Tigers# as they were dubbed – into one of Argyll#s most beautul settings and a possible murder.My book was intended to give the story of the local people whose lives were punctuated by this ambitious construction project. Quite rightly, those Tunnel Tigers had been lauded in a number of publications. The work that was done hollowing out Argyll’s highest mountain to provide electricity for the nation was amazing.The plan for Cruachan – as for the other major hydro projects of the post World War II era – was conceived by Tom Johnston, to whom I dedicated my book. Johnston was a politician who remained true to his ideals of bringing rural Scotland into the modern world. There was no power in the Highlands, and without power there could be no industry and no prosperity. The engineering genius was Sir Edward MacColl, whose biographer Norrie Fraser called him #a maker of modern Scotland#.Cruachan was the first reversible pumped-storage system in the world. During its years of construction from  to , eminent international engineers visited the project to see how the water was pumped between two reservoirs through reversible turbine generators. At off-peak hours, the water was – is # pumped back up to the reservoir you see high up in the corrie above Loch Awe, held back by a dam that is now so much a part of our landscape. The loch itself is the lower reservoir.I had imagined that the scale of such a project – using Scotland’s top engineering companies who shipped in workers from other parts of the UK and Europe – would have been a cause for resentment and protest by local people.That, of course, failed to take account of the vision of the folk of Dalmally, Lochawe, and Taynuilt. Although it took men with engineering experience to blast the  miles of tunnels, hollow out the mountain itself, and construct the dam, there was also a need for a support army. There were clerks and porters, joiners and caterers, folk willing to let out a room, a caravan, a house, serve in a pub where just occasionally it was necessary to keep a baseball bat behind the bar to maintain bonhomie. The project kick started careers, fortunes and marriages, and gave the area good roads and a tourist industry.If you haven’t visited the hollow mountain or walked Cruachan’s slopes, make  the year you do.[In bold please] Cruachan: The Hollow Mountain is available from the Argyll Book Centre in Lochgilphead and all good book shops, along with Marian Pallister#s other books of local interest.PICS:The Pass of Brander before work started. no_aCruachanLe before the project # the Loch Awe Hotel with steamers. no_aCruachanThe Queen opening the project in October . no_aCruachanWorking on the  miles of tunnels. no_aCruachanWorking on the road to the dam, overlooking Loch Awe. no_aCruachan
