title: ex-labour-mp-suspended-over-remarks-on-jewish-community-reinstated-to-party
story: Jim Sheridan, a former Paisley and Renfrewshire North MP who is now a councillor in Renfrewshire, said he is "delighted" with the decision and his support for Labour will continue.The party launched an investigation following a complaint in August last year, reported to relate to a social media post in which he spoke about his loss of "respect and empathy" for the community amid the anti-Semitism row.In a statement issued on Friday, he reiterated his apology while calling his accusers "misguided".He said: "Today I was notied that my suspension from the Labour Party has been lted with no further action to be taken by the party."Whilst I am delighted with this decision, I remain of the view that my accusers were misguided and overreacted to what was intended to highlight my personal frustration and criticism of those intent on undermining our leadership in Scotland and the UK."I would also like to reiterate my sincere apologies to the Jewish community whose historic struggle I have supported all my political le."Mr Sheridan said he had been "humbled" by the level of support he received.He added: "Throughout this unfortunate distraction I have maintained my total commitment to my constituents and will continue to do so."Likewise my complete support for the Labour Party and our leaderships at every level continues, and reinforces my determination toLabour administrations at local, devolved and national level, for the many not the few."It is understood Mr Sheridan will be issued with a reminder of party conduct.A Labour Party spokesman said: "The Labour Party takes all complaints of anti-Semitism extremely seriously and we are committed to challenging and campaigning against it in all its forms."All complaints about anti-Semitism are fully investigated in line with our rules and procedures and any appropriate disciplinary action is taken."

title: dark-history-linking-slavery-to-nations-historic-buildings-under-the-spotlight
story: New Lanark, Glasgowrsquos Gallery of Modern Art, and Edinburghrsquos James Gillespie schools are physical evidence of Scotlandrsquos wealthy past, but are all intimately connected with the slave trade.Now a government agency has announced it will carry out extensive research to determine how the countryrsquos links to the slavery helped finance some of our most treasured historic buildings.Once completed, the work by Historic Environment Scotlandwill enable the public to better understand a dark, but important part of the countryrsquos past.Scotlandrsquos involvement in the slave trade primarily spanned the th and th centuries.Following the act of unions and new-found access to the colonies, Scottish merchants became increasingly involved in the trade of sugar, tobacco, and cotton which were all produced on plantations in the Caribbean and the United States using slave labour.Some merchants took goods to Africa and exchanged or bought slaves and took them to the New World bringing back tobacco, sugar, and cotton.Other merchants relocated to the Caribbean and built their wealth on extensive use of extensive slave labour. At one stage,  per cent of Jamaicarsquos plantations were owned by Scottish families.The main links were with Glasgow, due to its status as a major trading port, and many of the streets in the city centre belie our chequered past including Jamaica Street, Virginia Street, and the Kingston Bridge.Other streets in the city - such as Buchanan Street, Glassford Street, Ingram Street and Wilson Street are named after the th century Tobacco Lords.But the wealth the Tobacco Lords and other merchants accrued, impacted right across the country, including country estates.Buildings funded by wealth garnered from such trade included the cotton mills in New Lanark, now a UNESCO World Heritage site, the National Trust of Scotland property Greenbank Garden, Glasgowrsquos Gallery of Modern Art, The Trades Halls in Glasgow, Inverness Academy, as well as the former Bathgate Academy, Dollar Academy, Inverness Academy, and Edinburghrsquos James Gillespie schools.Professor Tom Devine, a historian who edited the book Recovering Scotlandrsquos Slavery Past, said: ldquoThere was some trading of slaves in the early th century, but it was no more than , iniduals.ldquoA lot of Scots got involved in slave trading by emigrating to places such as London and Liverpool and working as traders, seamen, and doctors.ldquoThe largest impact in Scotland was through Scottish merchants involved in the tobacco, sugar and cotton trades, which could not have existed without slaves. We are talking about black chattel slavery which was the worst of all because slaves had no rights.Professor Devine welcomed the growing interest in Scotlandrsquos links to slavery and said the country was behind other parts of the UK in ldquorecovering its past.ldquoThis new work is transforming our understanding of Scottish history in the th and th centuries. Itrsquos important work. The major breakthroughs have been made by historians in the last ten years.ldquoWhy was it that Liverpool, Bristol, and London have accepted their role in this system from the s and s  Why does Scotland have this unwillingness or unawareness  ldquoThe HES plan to exhibit the historic buildings with links to the slave trade.Lorna Ewen, head of learning for HES, said they were ldquovery conscious of the need for greater clarity on how the ldquoprofits from slavery impacted on Scottish buildings.ldquoWe anticipate that this research will focus not only on the properties in Care Estate but also on the wider historic built environment: i.e Scotlandrsquos towns, cities, country estates, industrial sites. .ldquoWe are already in contact with relevant academics and other national and cultural heritage bodies, with the aim of taking forward an ambitious research project.

title: analysis-mps-face-another-moment-of-truth-with-votes-on-brexit-options
story: But as Brexit Day on March  approaches, tensions are rising fast in Westminsterville.By Friday there were  amendments to the Brexit motion it will be up to John Bercow, the Commons Speaker, to decide which ones MPs will debate and vote on. And just to add more confusion to the already mind-numbing complexity of the parliamentary process, there are now amendments to the amendments.Essentially, there are two main proposals.One is to extend the Article  process to avoid a no-deal outcome and the other is to kill off the Irish border backstop by seeking ldquoalternative arrangements to avoid a hard border.Cross-party campaigners had been planning to put one down to secure a Peoplersquos Vote but pulled it this week because they did not have the support of Jeremy Corbyn.Indeed on Friday, Ian Lavery, the party Chairman and a close ally of the Labour leader, knocked back the hopes of those pushing for another EU vote by warning it would risk ldquoserious damage to the relationship between many citizens and politicians at Westminster.Labourrsquos official amendment calls for a permanent customs union and a strong relationship with the EU single market with the option of legislating for a public vote ie in line with the party conference resolution.However, three Labour MPs, including Edinburgh Southrsquos Ian Murray, have now put amendments down to Labourrsquos amendment, seeking to ensure a Peoplersquos Vote takes place.The first key amendment is the one calling for an extension to Article  put down by Labourrsquos Yvette Cooper.This would put Brexit Day back to December  . The idea is to give the Government time to negotiate a deal. It has support not only from Labour MPs but Conservative, Liberal Democrat and SNP ones too.What worries Whitehall about this move, unlike the others, is that it proposes new legislation to stop the clock on Brexit.The plan is to push Ms Cooperrsquos new bill through the Commons in one day: February . However, there is a plot brewing in the Lords ndash where there is no mechanism to curtail a debate ndash to filibuster and ldquotalk the law to death.Critics of the Cooper amendment smell a rat and believe delaying Brexit is just a ruse to get Britain to stay in.Some argue only pressure will force Brussels to budge on the backstop any delay would mean the EU could string things out, knowing a Peoplersquos Vote was just around the corner and the UK would vote to stay in.The second key amendment is now one backed by the leadership of the Tory backbench  committee: scrapping the backstop with ldquoalternative arrangements to avoid a hard border and backing the PMrsquos Withdrawal Agreement - subject to this change.Crucially, it seems, the Democratic Unionists are preparing to support this change and the authors of it are hoping Theresa May and her Government will also row behind it.Of course, whatever the Commons finally backs still has one more formidable hurdle to overcome ndash securing agreement from the EU, which has insisted it will not budge.Nothing is certain about how this showdown is going to end and who might forsake who.

title: orkney-named-best-place-to-live-in-the-uk
story: The Bank of Scotlandrsquos Quality of Le Survey winner took the top prize due to itshigh employment levels, low crime rate, strong exam results, smaller primary class sizes and good health and happiness scores.Shetland, which takes second place in the Scottish table, is the only other location north of the border to break into the UK top .Ricky Diggins, network director for the Bank of Scotland, said: ldquoOrcadians will be thrilled to learn that not only is their home the best place to live in Scotland, itrsquos now taken the crown for the whole of the UK.ldquoWith Shetland and Eilean Siar coming second and third in Scotland, itrsquos a clean sweep of the podium places for these island communities.ldquoTheir more remote locations may not appeal to everyone but with benefits including high employment, low crime rates, smaller class sizes and more affordable housing, people around the country will now be dreaming of a le spent on the isles.The archipelago is also home to neolithic sites such as the Ring of Brodgar and Maeshowe.At a UK level, Richmondshire in North Yorkshire took second place, followed by Rutland in the East Midlands, Hambleton in North Yorkshire and Eden in Cumbria in fth place.

title: cross-party-call-for-peoples-vote-before-rally-outside-holyrood
story: Scotlandrsquos Constitutional Relations Secretary Mike Russell called on Prime Minister Theresa May to ldquostart listening.He said Brexit should be halted and Article  extended to enable a the search for the missing aircraft continues.Mr Choo said the club has also informed authorities it wants the search restarted.He reiterated the club had not organised Salarsquos travel arrangements as it did not have ldquojurisdiction over the new signing at the time of the flight.He described Sala as a ldquohumble man and a ldquohero who was ldquoreally looking forwardhellip to joining Cardf City.It could take six months to a year for investigators to collate information on what happened to the plane, Mr Choo claimed.His comments came afterit emerged accident investigators will examine whether the pilot had the correct licence.The Air Accidents Investigation Branchopened a probe after the light aircraft disappeared from radar on Monday night.ldquoWe are looking at all operational aspects of the flight, including licensing, an AAIB spokesman said.Mr Ibbotson, , of Crowle, Lincolnshire, held a private pilotrsquos licence and passed a medical exam as recently as November, according to Federal Aviation Administration records.The Civil Aviation Authority said the aircraft was registered in the US, so fell under American regulations.US law states private pilots cannot make a profit by carrying passengers.The flight left Nantes in France for Cardf at .pm on Monday, and after requesting to descend, lost contact with Jersey air traffic control over the English Channel.Cardf City had signed Sala for a club record pound million to bolster their attack and he was due to start training on Tuesday.Rescue teams scanned around , square miles and examined mobile phone data and satellite imagery but found no trace of the aircraft.Three planes and five helicopters racked up  hoursrsquo combined flying time looking for the plane, working alongside two leboats and other passing ships.

title: engineer-reunited-with-old-friend-as-rocket-returns-to-uk-after-50-years
story: The Black Arrow programme completed four rockets between  and , with the third flight marking the first and only successful UK-led orbital launch.A six-metre section of the projectile crash-landed in South Australia, and it remained there for  years.Derek Mack was among those in attendance as the rocket was unveiled in Midlothian on Friday, following a ,-mile journey back to the UK.The -year-old, from the Isle of Wight where the Black Arrow was developed and tested, was a senior trial engineer on the rocket project.He said: ldquo very interesting, the best time Irsquove ever had in my le as an engineer.ldquoIt was unique and in those days it was very advanced. We tended to get a bit of a reputation, like what an astronaut might get today.ldquoI have seen it, on photographs, it was interesting to look over it to see the actual detail of the damage and the ious things that survived.ldquoBut really it was like meeting an old friend, because the last time I saw it was as it lted off the launcher to take Prosperoup to orbit.Mike Kelloway had been a site inspector during the projectrsquos development.The -year-old, also from the Isle of Wight, said: ldquoIt was good fun, it was always up against the clock ndash Irsquove spent a night with this thing.ldquoTo see it now, when I can think of all the people I knew that worked on this ndash close friends some, colleagues, and a lot of them are no longer with us.ldquoTo be here now and see it ndash I never expected to see it again.Speeches were made by representatives from the UK Space Agency, the Royal Air Force and the London Science Museum.The rocket, which is being exhibited in a storage facility in Penicuik, was ed to the UK by Edinburgh space company Skyrora to be used for educational purposes.Skyrora director Daniel Smith said: ldquoWith the UK Governmentrsquos aim to make us a launch nation again, it seemed like the perfect time to bring Black Arrow back.ldquoWe hope itrsquos a reminder not only to our own team, but to everyone thatrsquos part of the new commercial space race of whatrsquos been accomplished before.ldquoIt has been some journey ndash we wouldnrsquot have been able to do it without the support of the William Creek Progress Association and the Australian Government, so wersquore extremely grateful to both.ldquoWe really hope the rocket will help to inspire current and future generations of scientists and engineers.In July last year, the UK Space Agency announced pound. million of funding for a proposed vertical launch spaceport in Sutherland, in the far north of Scotland.

title: charity to mark 140th anniversary with celebratory ball
story: Local charity North East Sensory Services will mark  years of improving lives with a celebratory Ball to remember.The charity operates with the main aim of achieving independence for blind and deaf people.The prestigious Ball event will take place at Aberdeens five-star Marclfe Hotel on Friday, March .A wonderful line-up of entertainment will be topped with a live performance set from singer, radio and television presenter, Aled Jones MBE.Aled has been a household name since the s, and will be forever noted as having been one of the worlds most successful boy sopranos.He is best known for singing Walking in the Air in the animated film, The Snowman.His theatre work is world famous too, having enjoyed starring roles including Joseph in Andrew Lloyd Webbers Joseph and the Amazing Technicolour Dreamcoat.The Ball event will be hosted by Emmerdale favourite Chris Chittell, best known for his role as Eric Pollard in the ITV soap.Entertainment will also be provided by top class live band Callanish.Stronachs are kindly sponsoring the champaign reception at the event.A spokesperson for the law firm said: "Stronachs are delighted to be associated with this long established charity and the services they provide to the blind and deaf communities, and are looking forward to being part of a fantastic launch event."Tickets for the Ball are still available for those who would like to join the guest list. title: house plan approved at oldmeldrum
story: The future of Oldmeldrum Golf Club has been secured thanks to councillors at the Formartine Area Committee.Plans to build a single house on land at the golf course went before councillors on Tuesday, January .The site in question is located directly behind an existing house next to the A and A junction.It is currently used for turf growing, but it had been classed as “obsolete” as it is cheaper for the Golf Club to buy new turfcompared to the man hours needed to maintain and cut their own.The planning application received a total of  representations, all of which were in support of the idea.However in a report put to councillors ahead of the meeting, council planners recommended that the plan be refused as the land had never been developed, and that the development itself was contrary to policy in the Aberdeenshire Local Development Plan.Speaking at the meeting on behalf of the club, Patricia Ramsay said that it is currently facing financial dficulties and the debt that it has is preventing the club from moving forward.She added: “The sale of this unused piece of land is the only way of raising much needed funds.“This would be a leline to this community asset.”After discussing the plan, councillor Paul Johnston suggested that the plans be approved with a delegated grant, and his decision was backed by councillor Karen Adam.Cllr Johnston said: “We have to think about the public circumstances, this is a private club but should it have to wind up, that would have a knock-on effect in the local community.”The proposal went to a vote and seven councillors backed the plan with just one vote against it.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! title: ice cream parlour to go orange for charity
story: Mackie#s of Scotland will colour their most popular flavour, known as #Traditional#, bright orange on Friday, February , to raise awareness and money for charity.Mackie’s ., their Aberdeen ice cream parlour, will be a bright vision with orange lighting, balloons and staff dressed in orange T-shirts for Muscular Dystrophy UK.Even the company’s logo will be converted to an orange spotted cow for the day. Alongside the orange Traditional ice cream, a parlour cabinet will be filled with over  orange tubs, each containing one of nine dferent prizes, from £ gt vouchers, to chocolate bars, so that customers can take part in a fundraising lucky dip.Mackie’s Marketing Director, Karin Hayhow said: “Muscular Dystrophy UK is a charity close to our hearts because we have experienced first-hand the severity of the illness.“We hope that our parlour customers have fun with the orange lucky dip infor a donation towards the work of Muscular Dystrophy UK.”The company is getting behind the day as part of their long-running support for people with any type of muscular dystrophy in Scotland.Muscular Dystrophy UK is the official charity for Mackie’s of Scotland and the joint venture company, Mackie’s at Taypack who make Mackie’s potato crisps and other savoury snacks.The association is founded on the personal experience of both companies, as Denis Emslie who worked as the Sales Director at Mackie’s of Scotland for  years, and Mark Taylor - brother of George Taylor, Managing Director at Mackie’s at Taypack - both lost their lives to forms of MD.Scotland’s Muscular Dystrophy UK Regional Development Manager, Dean Widd said: “We are incredibly grateful to our wonderful corporate partners Mackie’s of Scotland. There are just over , people in Scotland with muscular dystrophy and the money raised through Go Orange for a Day helps to fund our work into new treatments and campaigns for better care and support for people with muscle wasting conditions to live as independently as possible.”data-src"https:res. jpress image fetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.deesidepiper webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Aberdeenshire East MSP Gillian Martin"  Women urged to go for smear after uptake reaches all time low viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "ELLO | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "ELLO | Article Teaser"

title: inverurie play centre plans unveiled
story: Plans have been unveiled for a socially-inclusive soft play centre at an Inverurie industrial estate.Newly-formed charity ‘Because Everyone Counts’ wants to create the facility at a unit owned by Craigdon Mountain Sports at Burghmuir Circle.The group has been founded to provide a safe and inclusive play space for children from the local community from pre-school and nursery school age up to a maximum of  years.The applicants say the facility will be the first inclusive soft play centre within the North-east to offer adapted play to allow those with additional support needs to integrate with mainstream children.In a supporting statement to Aberdeenshire Council’s planning department, they say: “It will work together with local groups and schools such as St. Andrews offering somewhere safe to go.”A separate room will be available for children with limited communication and sensory disorders and will provide multi-sensory equipment.The facility would operate from .am to .pm seven days a week and the expected usage will be for a maximum of  children per day split into two-hour sessions.It is understood that special needs groups will arrive and be collected by mini-bus as will groups from local nurseries.If successful, the soft play centre would take up residence next to the Inverurie Gymnastics Club which also leases a unit.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! title: mackie s offers sweet take on burns night scran
story: Back by popular demand, Mackies of Scotland is relaunching its limited edition haggis and marmalade ice cream for Burns Night.The handcrafted speciality recipe – which has been made on the firms Westertown family farm – is available all weekend at Mackie’s . parlour in Aberdeen.The Burns Night treat will be available all weekendAt am this morning, piper Robert Reid from Deeside Caledonia Pipe Band piped the haggis ice cream in to the Marischal Square parlour.The ice cream has been made with Scotland’s famous Hall’s haggis, and has orange marmalade swirled through the mix.In celebration of Scotland’s Ploughman Poet, customers at . will be given free samples of the experimental dessert – and those who play a tune on the bagpipes will be able to enjoy any free scoop of their choice.Yvette Harrison, Parlour Manager at Mackie’s ., said: “While Marmalade is not a traditional accompaniment for Haggis – we added a ripple to help make this Scottish delicacy a little tastier when served cold in ice cream. And, of course a nip of whisky can also be drizzled over the top to raise a cone to the Bard.“Our haggis ice cream was such a hit last year that we just had to bring it back for Burns Night . Since last year’s limited edition batch, we’ve had people visit the parlour specically to try the flavour. So this weekend is the perfect opportunity for those who didn’t get the chance the first time round to satisfy their curiosity – and their taste buds.”Mackie’s is encouraging the public to share their thoughts on the creation with the hashtag #taemackiesicecream.Yvette added: “We love experimenting with our flavours at Mackie’s, and in celebration of Burns we’re challenging everyone to step outside their comfort zone, and try a scoop of our latest creation."data-src"https:res. jpress image fetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.ellontimes webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Singer, radio and television presenter Aled Jones MBE will perform a live set at the event"  Charity to mark th anniversary with celebratory Ball viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "ELLO | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "ELLO | Article Teaser"

title: top quality entries set to take part in the royal northern spring show
story: Entries are up on the year for next month#s annual multi-breed show and sale of pedigree bulls staged alongside the Royal Northern Spring Show at Thainstone.The sale, to be held on Wednesday, February , has attracted  entries from breeders across the north and north-east, and will include Aberdeen-Angus, Charolais, Limousins, Simmentals, Salers, Herefords, Beef Shorthorns and one British Blue.Last year’s sale saw a top price and a new centre record of ,gns paid for a Simmental bull from the MacPherson family at Blackford, Croy. This was Blackford Hero, by the ,gns Kilbride Farm Double Action, which sold across the water to a breeder in Northern Ireland. The MacPhersons have entered two Simmental bulls for next month’s sale, one of which was bought as a calf at foot from the Deerhurst dispersal and is by the ,gns Blackford Findhorn. The other bull from Blackford is one of the first sons of Blackford Galaxy.At the same sale last year, Charolais bulls produced the second lead price of gns for one from Charles McCombie and family of Auchincrieve, Rothiemay, near Huntly. The same home has entered three Charolais bulls this year, as well as one Aberdeen-Angus bull.Top price in the Aberdeen-Angus section at ’s sale was gns paid for a bull from father and son team, Neil and Mark Wattie, Mains of Tonley, near Alford. Tonley has entered three Aberdeen-Angus bulls for this year’s sale.Among the Limousins last year, the overall champion in the pre-sale show from Harry and Lynwen Emslie, Kinknockie, Mintlaw, topped at gns. Reserve was another Limousin from Andrew Gammie, Drumforber, Laurencekirk, which made gns. In all, this year’s bull entries stand at  Aberdeen-Angus,  Charolais,  Limousins,  Simmentals, eight Salers, two Herefords, two Beef Shorthorns and one British Blue. Two pedigree Limousin females have also been entered for the sale. John Angus, Head of Livestock for Aberdeen and Northern Marts, said: “We have a strong entry of quality bulls forward again this year and prices paid in the past for bulls demonstrates the standard of stock brought forward."This sale is a great opportunity for breeders to acquire top class bulls from established breeders in the area.”data-src"https:res. jpress image fetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.buchanobserver webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Banff and Buchan MP David Duguid"  MP tables amendment to Fisheries Bill on CFP exit date viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "BUCH | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "BUCH | Article Teaser"

title: women urged to go for smear after uptake reaches all time low
story: A north east MSP is encouraging women to go for their smear test to help reduce their risk of cervical cancer after it was revealed uptake is at an all time low.It comes as the charity Jo’s Cervical Cancer Trust aims to raise awareness during Cervical Cancer Prevention Week.More than , women are diagnosed with cervical cancer every year in the UK.Cervical screeningare the best protection against the disease, followed by the HPV vaccine offered in schools.Figures have revealed that last year, cervical screening uptake in Scotland fell from .% to .% meaning that more than one in four eligible women missed their screen test.This week Jo’s Cervical Cancer Trust has published new research which has found young women who delay or don’t go for cervical screening feel scared , vulnerableand embarrassedat the thought of going.A worrying two thirdssay they would not feel in control at the prospect of a test.Aberdeenshire East MSP Gillian Martin said: “I am delighted to be working with Jo’s Cervical Cancer Trust this Cervical Cancer Prevention Week.“Cervical screening prevents up to % of cervical cancers developing, so it is worrying to hear that so many women are not attending this test when invited, particularly due to embarrassment.“It’s a small test which can make a huge dference so I would urge women to encourage daughters, nieces, other family and friends who are eligible for the test to do so.”Robert Music, Chief Executive of Jo’s Cervical Cancer Trust said: “We are delighted to have Gillian Martin’s support to help raise awareness about the importance of cervical screening.Smear tests provide the best protection against cervical cancer yet we know they aren’t always easy.“We want women to feel comfortable talking to their nurse and asking questions. It’s not making a fuss and there are many ways to make the test easier. Please don’t let your fears stop you booking a test.” data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Police Scotland"  Two taken to hospital after crash viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: workshop to develop artwork ideas for new kintore rail station
story: A day of workshops to develop ideas for potential future artwork at the new Kintore Rail Station will take place on Saturday .People living in the town and surrounding communities are invited to take part in the event, which will run from .am to .pm in Kintore Church Hall.Anyone who wants to be involved, but without taking part in the workshop sessions, is welcome to simply drop-in throughout the day.Studio Niro, a multidisciplinary design practice, is organising the event in collaboration with Aberdeenshire Council. The workshops will involve colour mixing and print making to create a library of Kintore colours and shapes which will then be used to develop artwork.The sessions will take place from .am-pm and from -.pm and members of the community are asked to bring along a camera and any old photos of Kintore they may have. Free tickets can be booked at www.krsartwork.eventbrite or by calling   . The new railway station is part of the wider Aberdeen to Inverness Improvement Project .A representative from Network Rail will be available during the day to provide information on the project and forthcoming related works in .The workshops also provide the opportunity to re-unite for the first time in at least fty years two benches installed at the original Kintore Station, which was closed in the late s.Prior to their restoration, both benches will be on display for members of public to see. title: Caithness Moray link is completed
story: THE Caithness-Moray electricity transmission link will support deployment of renewable energy in the north of Scotland for many years to come, the man who led the project has said.Dave Gardner, director of transmission for Scottish and Southern Electricity NetworksTransmission, was speaking after it was announced that the construction, commissioning and energisation of the link had been completed at a cost of around pound million.He hailed it as a signicant achievement for SSEN and everyone involved."Caithness-Moray has been a highly complex project, requiring very high standards of project design, development, construction and commissioning," Mr Gardner said. "It has been delivered by a team of committed and skilled people, working closely with contractors and other stakeholders."It will support deployment of renewable energy in the north of Scotland for many years to come."Now an operational asset, we will closely monitor the link and associated infrastructure to ensure its continued success as an integral part of the GB transmission system."We would like to thank all those who contributed to the success of the project, from our own teams of engineers and support staff, our supply chain and the local communities who have played host to our project teams over recent years."Caithness-Moray is the largest single investment ever undertaken by the SSE Group and is described as the most signicant investment in the north of Scotland electricity transmission system since the s.The link uses HVDCtechnology to transmit power through a km subsea cable beneath the Moray Firth seabed between new converter stations at Spittaland Blackhillock . Constructed over a period of four years, the project also involved work at eight electricity substation sites.Completed on time and within the allowance approved by the regulator Ofgem, the Caithness-Moray link provides up to MW of capacity to transmit power from the increasing sources of renewable energy from across the far north.The link has already enabled turbines from Beatrice offshore wind farmand Dorenell onshore wind farmto connect to the national grid with a further MW of onshore generation in Caithness and Ross-shire due to connect in the coming months.The completion of the link and other electricity transmission projects is expected to help take the Regulatory Asset Valueof SSEN Transmission to around pound. billion at March , .Saturday  Jan  : AM

title: Did aliens visit Wick
story: While millions of people around the country were cheering on the fireworks that brought in the new year, a Wick man and his family say they were witnessing a light show they never expected.Charlie Williamsonsays he had just popped out the back door of his house at Leishman Avenue after the bells sounded at midnight, only to spot a strange light overhead.He beckoned his we Tanya and their three children onto the doorstep from where he says they observed the strange object with flashing lights that ldquohovered in one place for over three hours.Speaking to the Courier, he says he wasnrsquot the only one to witness the eerie phenomenon.ldquoA local woman and some people south of the town also witnessed the strange sight.After Charlie posted a video of his sighting online, media ndash including the Scottish Sun ndash ran stories on his UFO experience.Many readers, however, wrote off the object as merely a drone.Charlie says he is ldquo per cent sure that is not the case.ldquoIt was way too big, he says. ldquoI donrsquot know much about drones other than the size of them but a few people have messaged me saying they wonrsquot fly for a solid three hours. It was windy that night too and a lot of people who fly drones have told me it wouldrsquove been too windy that night to fly one.Keith Banks, an amateur meteorologist who writes a monthly weather column for the John OrsquoGroat Journal, says mphgusts were blowing during the period the UFO was witnessed.ldquoIn my view the very blustery conditions would have effectively precluded a drone from flying, he said.Dedicated drone flyers agree, including Barry Scollay from Wick who says he has been flying the unmanned aerial vehicles for a decade.ldquoNo way a drone would have flown in those winds ndash thatrsquos a certain fact, said Mr Scollay, who has a Facebook page called Highland Aerial Views which has over , followersldquoIt would have to have been able to maintain its location in high winds. Irsquove flown very large drones in mph wind but that was the limit, he says.ldquoYou can [even] hear the wind howling in his video.Whatrsquos more, he says that software in operation at the nearby Wick airport would not allow such a drone to take off.Small hobby drones ldquocanrsquot fly within the airportrsquos no-fly zone.Charlie reckons the UFO was about ft above his head, larger than a car and made no sound.Although he took photos and video on his smartphone he admits that the quality was not the best.ldquoIt was like seeing a car at the bottom of your street, it was that clear. Itrsquos just not as clear with the phone.The object disappeared not long after a police van appeared at around am.ldquoI couldnrsquot get to sleep and kept going to the window and the door to see it but it was gone, he says.Since posting the video online he has had numerous calls from self-professed ldquoUFO investigators.Therersquos been so many of them, he says hersquos now ldquovery waryof callers who ask ldquotoo many questions.ldquoItrsquos like being interviewed by the FBI, he said. ldquoVery weird and over the top with the secrecy.Since his sighting, an organisation called the British Earth and Aerial Mysteries Societyhas said it believes he saw an ldquointerdimensional plasma craft.The craft have also been suggested as a cause for recent disruptions at Gatwick and Heathrow airports.A spokesperson for Wick John OrsquoGroats Airport confirmed that it was closed during the period the object was sighted, and there are also no reports of the emergency services operating in the air at that time.Charliersquos video can be seen at https:youtu.be xdHBiqtkWhat do you think he saw  Email d.scott@nosnwith your suggestions.Saturday  Jan  : AM

title: Plans to tackle Wick town centre parking hailed as very good news
story: Local Highland councillor Andrew Sinclair said he welcomed the proposals outlined in a traffic order as they give the local authority greater powers to deal with what has been a contentious issue for many years.Many other areas of Wick would also be subject to restrictions.Councillor Sinclair, who represents the Wick and East Caithness ward, said: "I think this is very good news for the town. We have been calling for more parking enforcement in Wick for a while now."High Street and Bridge Street are far too regularly packed with cars parked where they shouldnt be. Its an issue that has been raised time and time again by both drivers and pedestrians. Some people think they are above the rules and for too long theyve got away with it."He added: "Under the current proposals Bridge Street and much of High Street will essentially become double yellows, meaning no parking at any time. This should also help stop the constant issue of people selfishly parking in areas like the Market Square."The parking bays there are intended only for those who are disabled badge holders but these rules are often ignored by people who just canrsquot be bothered walking."Councillor Sinclair said the order would give council officers the power to enforce parking restrictions once they receive the required training but, initially, existing enforcement staff would carry out the work."We should expect a much more regular presence than under the old system," he said. "The discussions Irsquove had with the officer responsible for parking have been extremely encouraging."Having an enforcement officer in the town for regular and random visits is a great start butthe situation doesnrsquot improve we will still be pushing to get someone in this post locally to clamp down on rogue drivers."He explained that in Inverness several council employees have been trained to undertake parking enforcement duties as well as their day-to-day jobs. "There is no reason why the same couldnrsquot be done up here. If these orders get the go-ahead, and I am confident they will, then I hope we will begin to see a dference in peoples behaviour."The Caithness civic leader, Councillor Willie Mackay, also backed the plan. "It is a fantastic idea but it is the enforcement that is the key to the success of this," he said. "If we can get enough staff trained up to act as traffic wardens ndash and I am pretty sure we can ndash then their presence will deter bad parking."Parking in the centre of Wick has been a contentious problem for some time and has often been raised by the local community council and others. If this is approved, it will make a massive dference to the town centre, although there will always be some motorists who will take a chance and park there."However, Councillor Mackay has misgivings about the extent of the restrictions planned for other parts of Wick.Saturday  Jan  : AM

title: Trailblazers on right path
story: MEMBERS of Wick Paths Group joined forces with Friends of the John OGroats Trail to improve a path used by walkers visiting the Castle of Old Wick.They got stuck in to the task of upgrading the narrow, muddy and uneven section from the old rle range to the field at the Grey Bools. The path had been scraped out in advance by Nordwall Landscaping to a width of . metres and some  tonnes of quarry gravel had been purchased and delivered to site.On the work day  volunteers turned out to help and they were grateful for the heavy machinery loaned by Hugh Simpson , M M Miller and Graham Begg. The gravel was laid in just under three hours and has resulted in a much-improved route.Wick Paths Group chairman Allan Tait said: "We are very grateful to all the volunteers who turned out to help, to the landowners for giving permission and to the local businesses for lending their equipment. The path is very popular with local people for walking and running as well as the increasing use by those walking the John OGroats Trail."This section of path is now immensely better than it was and I hope it will encourage many more people to come out and walk the route."Jay Wilson, chairman of the John OGroats Trail group, said: "Im very pleased to see a great turnout of Wick volunteers to build a path for the town that also forms part of the overall John OGroats Trail."Saturday  Jan  : AM

title: Upgrade should just be the start
story: THE pound. million upgrade of the north section of the Berriedale Braes should be the trigger to improve the rest of that part of the A, according to Caithness councillor Raymond Bremner.He made the plea after Transport Scotland confirmed the contract to upgrade the notorious north hairpin bend has been awarded to Dingwall-based engineering company R J McLeod Ltd. Work is due to start this year, be completed by spring  and create  jobs during the construction phase.Councillor Bremner, who represents Wick and East Caithness on Highland Council, said: "While Im keen to see an improvement to the north brae, I still believe we cant take our focus off the south brae. We have two major long-term concerns to focus on here ndash the gradient of the brae and the fact that we are still witnessing serious accidents on the bottom hairpin bend even where there is an escape bed."These accidents are a risk to le, causing road closures and impacting in all sorts of ways on our local community and economy. Improvements to the north brae are very welcome and I hope that it is the start of a bigger vision to improve the entire Berriedale Braes."We can expect the standard lead-in period of about three months and for discussions to be held with the contractor on how they propose to physically approach the works and discussions with statutory bodies like the Scottish Environment Protection Agency and the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds among others."He said that archaeological investigatory works have been completed.The award of the contract was also welcomed by Trudy Morris, chief executive of Caithness Chamber of Commerce.She said: "We are delighted to see that after many years of dedicated campaigning by the chamber, Caithness Transport Forum and other local organisations, this project is finally moving ahead. For too long, the Berriedale Braes has acted as a pinch point for travellers on the A north of Inverness, disrupting business and jeopardising investment in the region."It has been good to see other work on A improvements and repairs going to local companies in recent years, and we hope the principal contractor will engage closely with our highly skilled local supply chain as these works progress."Ms Morris added: "Now that the contract has been formally awarded, we hope to see clarication on exact start dates and expectedof works very soon. We would urge the Scottish Government to uphold its previous promise to start works within this financial year so that the north Highlands can start to see the benefit of this upgrade as soon as possible."A Transport Scotland spokesman said: "R J McLeod Ltd has been awarded the construction contract as part of the pound. million project to deliver improvements to the road alignment and the existing tight hairpin bend on the A."Michael Matheson, cabinet secretary for transport, hailed it as a positive development for the area. "It will enhance the skills development of the Scottish construction industry, with approximately  jobs expected to be supported in the region during construction."Related articles:Four in running for Berriedale Braes contractSilence on A schemeSaturday  Jan  : AM

title: We have saved part of our identity
story: THE Dunnet and Canisbay area would have lost part of its identityits community council had been scrapped due to boundary changes, vice-chairman Bill Mowat has said.He welcomed last weeks change of heart by Highland Council and said he was very pleased the body had been saved.Under the proposals, Dunnet and Canisbay would have been linked with Castletown and Bower community councils.Mr Mowat said the area would have lost part of its identitythe plan, which would also have seen the demise of Sinclairs Bay Community Council, went ahead.Details were reported in the John OGroat Journal last Friday."Community councils are of real value when you have got a single-tier council and you dont have a councillor representing the area," Mr Mowat said. "We are very pleased with the outcome which is a small victory for localism."We are relieved we are to continue. There was an indicationthis proposal was forced through most members would not have bothered to continue attending meetings."Mr Mowat pointed out that Canisbay and Dunnet are historic settlements based on a crofting background and said that would have been lost under the plan. "We are delighted we are to continue. This decision keeps our identity in this north-east corner which goes back to the end of the th century," he said.He stressed there had been strong opposition to the plan and added: "It is hardly our fault , as is being claimed, some neighbouring community councils may not be ing as well as some observers might desire. Dunnet and Canisbay should not be punished for this."Mr Mowat explained that Highland councillor Andrew Sinclairhad made the case for retention as he is the current local authority representative on Dunnet and Canisbay Community Council. Councillor Sinclair made a similar plea to retain Sinclairs Bay Community Council whose future was also threatened. Part of its area would have been linked with Wick.Saturday  Jan  : AM

title: Wicks Francis Street Club closes
story: Wick institution the Francis Street Club has been forced to close due to financial dficulties. ldquoIt was decided by the committee to close the Francis Street Club and Institute Limited at midnight on Wednesday, January , , the spokesperson, who did not wish to be named, said.A note subsequently posted on its door read: ldquoWe have ceased trading from immediate effect at these premises the Francis Street Club Wick. All other details will follow in due course.The building first opened as a British Legion in the s, and remained a popular focal point for the community.It served as a social club and ran football and darts teams ndash both well-supported by members.It also operated as an entertainment venue, with music and entertainment acts from across the country putting in appearances to local acclaim.One famous occasion took place in  when Councillor Willie Mackay was able to persuade top darts players Jocky Wilson and Eric Bristow to play an exhibition match ndash a fixture Scotsman Wilson won.However, it is expected that such nights will now become a thing of the past.It is not known what the future of the building holds, orany parties are considering taking the club over.The spokesperson stressed the committee was ldquovery sad the club had to close.Saturday  Jan  : AM

title: invitation to tender issued for northern isles ferry contract
story: An Invitation to Tender for the next contract to run the Northern Isles ferry services has been issued to three bidders, the Scottish Government announced today, Thursday.Submission of final tenders is scheduled for March, with a view to awarding the contract in July.The contract is estimated to be worth £m and will run for eight years. The names of the companies involved have however, not been released.Minister for energy, connectivity and the islands, Paul Wheelhouse, said: “Issuing the Invitation to Tender marks the next stage of the process to award the new contract to operate the Northern Isles Ferry Services.“The contract will run for eight years, allowing us to build a strong working relationship with the successful bidder, and all the routes within the network are being tendered as a single bundle.“The Scottish Government remains fully committed to high quality ferry services to the Northern Isles. A key benefit of this new contract is the in-built flexibility, allowing the ferry services to be amended to reflect future changes in demand across the important sectors of the islands’ economies – tourism, fishing, food and drink, aquaculture and farming. Scottish Ministers will also retain control of all of important issues, such as fares and timetables, through the public service contract.“We are committed to a fair, open and transparent tender which aims to get the best possible deal for the communities that depend on these ferry services.”• Commenting on the issue, Northern Isles MSP’s Liam McArthur and Tavish Scott said: “The Scottish Government have finally issued the tender. The timescale is very tight indeed given the operator needs to be up and running the North Isles leline ferry services in  months’ time. It is essential that companies make constructive bids with improvements to the existing service. It must, in particular, recognise the growing freight volumes that are being exported south to the Scottish mainland.“So the tender bids must be properly assessed to ensure the service moves forward and not backwards. And the endless saga of RET must come to an end, otherwise how can bidding companies submit a proposed fare policy ”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: oic makes urgent call for ferry funding
story: Orkney Islands Council is again calling on the Scottish Government to honour a commitment to provide fully fair funding for the county’s inter-island ferry service — or it will hand the service back to the government to run.The council is warning it cannot afford to run the service during the year ahead unless the government covers the full cost involved — this amounts to £. million. OIC Leader James Stockan has notied Ministers that the council will hand over responsibility for running the service to Transport Scotland, unless sufficient funding is provided.A year ago, a similar level of support was secured, after a y campaign by OIC for fair funding. Of this, £. million was allocated to fully fund Orkney’s internal ferry service during the current financial year, with £ million awarded to Shetland Islands Council for its ferry operations.“But this time there is no specic amount allocated to Orkney or Shetland. The government recognises that it will cost £. million to operate our ageing fleet of ferries during - — and that is what we are asking the government to provide.”OIC is also looking to the government to fund the replacement of the current inter-island fleet. The council has been working with the government on this for a number of years and is currently developing a business case setting out the service levels local communities require, and the engineering options needed to achieve these.Councillor Stockan added: “We would object in the strongest possible termswe end up with a reduction in our ferries funding. This would place a wholly disproportionate and unfair burden on the smallest council in Scotland and would mean us having to make cuts to other vital services.“The ferries are a leline for remote and fragile communities across our islands. Orkney has the oldest fleet and the highest fares in the country — an inequality we cannot address without proper financial support from the Scottish Government.We are calling on the government to take an honourable approach to fulfilling the will of the Scottish Parliament that we should receive fair and equitable funding for our inter-island ferry service. The principle of transferring Orkney’s internal ferry service to the Scottish Government, at no net detriment to OIC, has already been approved by the council. That is a route we will have to take unless we are provided with the funds to run the service over the year ahead.”For the full story, pick up a copy of The Orcadian, this Thursday.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: Bid to get folk behind Dingwall improvement project
story: BUSINESSES keen to help regenerate Ross-shirersquos county town are being asked to show their support by getting surveys paving the way for a new development project lodged within days.The Dingwall Means Business group is behind plans for a business improvement districtwhich could mirror the success of a similar scheme in Inverness.BID manager George Murray said the group was now ldquowell into its year of listening and talking to all businesses in and around Dingwall to promote a lsquoyesrsquo for BID for the town.He said: ldquoNearly  surveys have gone out and we are still looking for a few more to be ed. The success of the Dingwall BID depends upon our local businessesrsquo support.ldquoWe are working hard to gather information from all the businesses in Dingwall and we need to hear from everyone. This is your chance to have your say and add to the overall business plan. Then all you have to do is vote yes in the ballot and we can make these projects happen.ldquoWe really want to make sure that nobody is missed and that everyone gets their opportunity to vote because this could be a monumental time in our townrsquos history. This could become the year when Dingwall businesses take control over the townrsquos economic future.Mr Murray said: ldquoWe are aware that there must be a decenton their investment. I believe Highland Council currently collect a wee bit more than pound million per annum from non-domestic ratepayers and Irsquove calculated that the levy would need to be between . to three per cent.ldquoThis would allow us to invoice the council for approximately pound,. Itrsquos also possible we would be able to almost match fund this figure from other sources. This would be an amazing amount banked in Dingwall to be spent on Dingwall. This is how we would fund the five-year plan ready to start after a yes vote.He wants remaining surveys, seeking feedback from businesses to a number of questions, ed by Friday, February .Survey results will then be collated with a five-year business plan set to be drafted by the end of March. A yes no vote on BID would then be held in May.Gordon McIntosh, practice manager of Munro  Noble, is a director of BID Inverness and believes the scheme can pay idends for Dingwall too.He said ldquocoach ambassadors had brought more tourists into the city, increasing spend. It meant local businesses were stakeholders in any centre development plans and have the ability to lobby the council over issues of interest. The scheme also paved the way for successful events such as classic car shows, Easter egg hunts and bar and business awards.He said: ldquoWith representatives from a cross section of businesses on the board the strong advocacy we have provided has achieved some notable results. These results have been for the betterment of our business and social community. A healthier, connected community drives profit opportunities.Saturday  Jan  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Business masterclass aims to put Highland entrepreneurs ahead
story: ENTREPRENEURS will learn how to create and sustain a competitive advantage at an event in Inverness next month.Professor Eleanor Shaw, executive director of the Hunter Centre for Entrepreneurship and vice dean of Strathclyde Business School, will deliver a masterclass on February  and  at the Kingsmills Hotel in Inverness.The event, which includes a networking dinner, is organised by Highlands and Islands Enterpriseas part of its entrepreneurship programme.Prof Shaw said: ldquoBy creating a competitive advantage, businesses can set a buffer between them and their competitors in turn creating a more secure place in the market.ldquoThe way in which we approach executive education at the University of Strathclyde is dferent ndash we put the focus on the participant in the room, looking at their needs and providing access to toolkits and learning so after the masterclass they can start working with colleagues and honing their value proposition straight away.ldquoEverything we do has been road tested by working with entrepreneurs and wersquove learned that creating a competitive advantage can help a business in many ways.ldquoIrsquom really looking forward to working with Highlands and Islands entrepreneurs, sharing our learnings and making new connections in the region.Louise MacDonald, senior entrepreneurship manager at HIE, said: ldquoCreating and sustaining a competitive advantage can be dficult in todayrsquos ever-changing and dynamic environment.ldquoBusinesses need to think strategically and be able to analyse their proposition to find ways to enhance impact, value and performance.ldquoThe masterclass will teach entrepreneurs from across the region the tools and techniques to stay ahead of the game.For more information, email entrepreneurship@hient or visit www.hie masterclassesSaturday  Jan  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Conon Bridge school travel plan set for an upgrade
story: PARENTS of children in a village that has witnessed a surge in housebuilding are being asked to have their say on a new school travel plan.The appeal centres on Ben Wyvis Primary in Conon Bridge. A survey has been issued seeking information on issues such as what factors influence parentsrsquo decisions on whether to let their children walk or cycle to school and how much they value safer crossings, vehicle speed-reduction measures and improved road safety education as well as information on the benefits of walking and cycling.The survey includes questions about the distance pupils attending Ben Wyvis Primary live from the school and the modes of transport they use to get there.It also seeks views on measures that could reduce congestion at the school gate. These include involvement in voluntary cycle training and a car sharing scheme.Itrsquos part of a wider effort across the Highlands to work on safer routes to school, reduce unnecessary car use and encourage healthier alternatives where possible, such as walking and cycling.The survey, supported by the parent council, can be found online and completed at www.surveymonkey r BenWyvisPSSaturday  Jan  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Easter Ross filmmaker turned author gets to art of matter in new novel
story: Tain-based Mike Herd had plenty of time to ponder plots when he worked as a cameraman on more than  films, many requiring endless patience to capture unforgettable footage.His latest novel, The Medusa Shield, is a ldquomystical fantasy set in the fictitious village of Rockburn on the eastern seaboard of the Black Isle. Set in , it sees protagonist Scott and his father James take the car ferry across the Beauly Firth to Inverness as they watch men working on the Kessock Bridge.Scott agrees to attend a farm roup with his father and feels he is being watched by a yellow eye from a dirty painting hanging amongst the lots. Unknown to his father, he successfully bids for it and his le starts to alter in remarkable ways.The action swings between Aberdeen and Florence as Scott embarks on a journey of discovery.Mr Herd, who describes himself as ldquo going on , said time spent alone working on so many films served him.He said: ldquoBy the nature of film work there wasnrsquot a typical day because all trips y. The most memorable film that I have worked on must be Swamp Tigers in the Bangladeshi Sundarbans.ldquoUsing a converted river ferry boat as a mobile base, a typical day would be, rising at four and travelling in the dark to a hide built on stilts embedded in a channel.ldquoI would stay there on my own usually for twelve hours and I did that for months. Being in a hide that long gives you plenty of time to think.ldquoLying awake in bed in the morning, plot ideas and characters nag at me and I have to get up to write about them.ldquoI am a hopeless two-fingered typist which is very frustrating because they canrsquot keep up with whatrsquos going through my head. That aside It does surprise me how easy it is for me to write, I donrsquot know where that comes from. I try to write at least a thousand words a day but quite often Irsquoll hit a brick wall.ldquoI donrsquot worry about that because I know that I will get the inspiration to carry on later.ldquoI try to write about what I know, itrsquos much more convincing and I use locations Irsquove been to. For example, in The Medusa Shield, Scott goes full moon night fishing off the Black Isle coast in a Zulu boat. While I was in India the fishermen on the east coast do that every month.The Medusa Shield is available from Amazon Kindle, Kobo and other digital publishers.Saturday  Jan  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Fresh deal is a sign of our intent says firm at Invergordon port
story: A MAJOR engineering firmrsquos decision to extend its contract at the Port of Cromarty Firth is a sign of its ldquocommitment to the area and wider UK market, its operations manager has said,Offshore project and engineering company Semco Maritimersquos decision to extend its use of the portrsquos Queens Dock facility follows its busiest ever year.In  ious vessels stayed in Queens Dock along with Maersk Reacher, which received reactivation upgrades over  months, and Maersk Innovator, which spent two months on site for the upgrade and installation of a cantilever extension.In the five years it has operated at the site Semco Maritime has carried out works on drilling rigs, pipe lay vessels, accommodation rigs, survey vessels, cargo boats and ious other projects, and has hosted numerous rigs.ldquoThe extension of our existing contract for Queens Dock shows Semco Maritimersquos commitment to maintain and strengthen our presence in the UK, said Neil Robertson, operations manager at Semco Maritime, Invergordon.ldquoWe have seen our department in Invergordon flourish and deliver great service to our clients, not least thanks to a productive agreement with Port of Cromarty Firth with both parties fully behind repairs, upgrades and maintenance projects,The firm described Invergordon as a perfect base for ious offshore service projects, which had made it possible to carry out repairs, upgrades and maintenance for rigs in operation as far away as Malaysia, Australia and the Gulf of Mexico.Bob Buskie, chief executive of the Port of Cromarty Firth said Semco Maritimersquos presence ldquohas made Invergordon an attractive port for drilling contractors and subsea operators undertaking inspection, repair and maintenance projects.Saturday  Jan  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Highland arts venue has strategy to combat fund gap
story: THE regionrsquos biggest arts venue has outlined how it must become more financially resilient.In its latest accounts, Eden Court in Inverness reported increased income and more expenditure in the year ending March ,  compared to the previous  months.Last year Eden Court lost pound, a year of funding ndashpound, from Creative Scotland and pound, from the Highland Council.A trusteesrsquo report the figures stated: ldquoThe principal risks identied are financial ones, particularly the effect of this yearrsquos signicant reduction in public funding.ldquoThe organisation must become more financially resilient by growing sources of earned income and building a safe level of reserves.ldquoAs public funding declines, the targets for earnings from trading activities necessarily increase, and the risk that these targets cannot be met also increases. At the same time, our cost base is likely to increase owing to inflationary pressures on resources.ldquoThis year we are working on a strategy for trading through our funding gap, increasing income from charitable trading, reducing costs wherever possible and developing partnerships to share services.ldquoAttention has also been focused on non-financial risks arising from the loss of some channels of regular communication with our major funders our relationship with both Creative Scotland and the Highland Council has been strengthened during the year to March ,  and subsequently.ldquoThe development of positive relationships with funders ndash public organisations and inidual philanthropists ndash remains a high priority and is a central part of Eden Courtrsquos financial strategy for the coming three years.Total income increased from pound,, in  to pound,, last year. For the same period, total expenditure moved from pound,, to pound,,.Total funds also went up from pound,, to pound,,.Advance ticket sales mean that Eden Courtrsquos cash flow position remains strong.The biggest event of the year was the Snow White panto, which sold more than , tickets for its  performances.The report stated: ldquoAttendance for the year has been unprecedented with audiences of , for live performances and , at film screenings. title: Life saving Ross shire Womens Aid centre issues action plan after mixed report
story: The Dingwall-based Ross-shire Womenrsquos Aid centre has received a mixed inspection report from the Care Commission watchdog.While the quality of care and support provided to abused women and their children was judged good, the quality of management and leadership was rated ldquoadequate.One woman told inspectors that the service was a le-saver and she wished it would receive more funding.However there were times when staff felt inadequately supported by management, said the report following the unannounced inspection. story: A BID to save an under-threat gardening project for learning disabled adults in Easter Ross has won public support amid growing efforts to secure its long-term future.NHS Highland has withdrawn its funding for the initiative at the Isobel Rhind Centre in Invergordon, saying it cannot afford it.But at least , people have signed a petition backing the initiative and more than pound of a pound, target to fund a six-month extension has been raised thanks to the support of well-wishers responding to a crowdfunding drive set up by Cromarty Firth councillor Maxine Smith.A local businessman has also promised to match fund whatever is raised through the drive.Cllr Smith said thateveryone who signed the petition chipped in just pound, it would ensure a breathing space for the  users who have helped brighten up Invergordon with hanging baskets.Efforts to find a new model to deliver the scheme have been going on behind the scenes and NHS Highland has said that although funding will stop, the land at the centre can continue to be used.
